editorialDecl.p: EEBO-TCP is a partnership between the Universities of Michigan and Oxford and the publisher ProQuest to create accurately transcribed and encoded texts based on the image sets published by ProQuest via their Early English Books Online (EEBO) database (http://eebo.chadwyck.com). The general aim of EEBO-TCP is to encode one copy (usually the first edition) of every monographic English-language title published between 1473 and 1700 available in EEBO.

EEBO-TCP aimed to produce large quantities of textual data within the usual project restraints of time and funding, and therefore chose to create diplomatic transcriptions (as opposed to critical editions) with light-touch, mainly structural encoding based on the Text Encoding Initiative (http://www.tei-c.org).

The EEBO-TCP project was divided into two phases. The 25,363 texts created during Phase 1 of the project have been released into the public domain as of 1 January 2015. Anyone can now take and use these texts for their own purposes, but we respectfully request that due credit and attribution is given to their original source.
Users should be aware of the process of creating the TCP texts, and therefore of any assumptions that can be made about the data.

Text selection was based on the New Cambridge Bibliography of English Literature (NCBEL). If an author (or for an anonymous work, the title) appears in NCBEL, then their works are eligible for inclusion. Selection was intended to range over a wide variety of subject areas, to reflect the true nature of the print record of the period. In general, first editions of a works in English were prioritized, although there are a number of works in other languages, notably Latin and Welsh, included and sometimes a second or later edition of a work was chosen if there was a compelling reason to do so.

Image sets were sent to external keying companies for transcription and basic encoding. Quality assurance was then carried out by editorial teams in Oxford and Michigan. 5% (or 5 pages, whichever is the greater) of each text was proofread for accuracy and those which did not meet QA standards were returned to the keyers to be redone. After proofreading, the encoding was enhanced and/or corrected and characters marked as illegible were corrected where possible up to a limit of 100 instances per text. Any remaining illegibles were encoded as <gap>s. Understanding these processes should make clear that, while the overall quality of TCP data is very good, some errors will remain and some readable characters will be marked as illegible. Users should bear in mind that in all likelihood such instances will never have been looked at by a TCP editor.
The texts were encoded and linked to page images in accordance with level 4 of the TEI in Libraries guidelines.

Copies of the texts have been issued variously as SGML (TCP schema; ASCII text with mnemonic sdata character entities); displayable XML (TCP schema; characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or text strings within braces); or lossless XML (TEI P5, characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or TEI g elements).
Keying and markup guidelines are available at the Text Creation Partnership web site.

div.p: THE REFORMATION. A COMEDY. ACTED At the Dukes Theater.
div.q: Sunt, quibus in Satyra videor nimis acer—
div.p: LONDON, Printed for William Cademan, at the Popes-Head, in the Lower walk of the New Exchange in the Strand, MDCLXXIII.

div.head: PROLOGUE.
div.l: I Smile to think how every One that's here,
Expects Tartuffe or Scrupple ſhould appear;
Who with Religions Twang and Mouth a-ſplay
Should Conventicle now inſtead of play:
But 't is the other houſe, you've loſt your way.
Here's nothing like a holy Reformation,
Nor Drum, nor Trumpet, though ſo much in Faſhion
In all admired Playes of th' new Tranſlation.
Nay can you Gueſs what our dull Rogue ſhould mean?
He ha's not left us Room for Gaudy Scene;
Which uſes to amuſe you for a time,
Whil'ſt Non-ſence ſafely glides away in Rime.
I'le ſwear I had advis'd him for the beſt,
To Lard it with fat Song or bawdy jeaſt
Or write in Verſe and huffe the Gods at leaſt.
But he was humourſome and bid me ſay,
He was for plodding in the Antient way:
Yet he would if this did not pleaſe our Friends,
In Rime and Non-ſence ſtrive to make amends.
If we procur'd Noiſe, Clothes, Scenes, Songs and Dance,
His Siege, or Conqueſt he can have from France.

list.label: Camillo an old ſevere Father.
Pacheco his Son a fop and a reformer.
Tutor to Pacheco an Engliſh-man.
Antonio Reformer.
Pedro Reformer.
Leandro in love with Iſmena.
Lyſander Husband to Juliana.
Piſauro Gallant to Juliana a Reformer.
Boy to Antonio.
Mariana daughter to Camillo.
Iſmena daughter to Camillo.
Juliana wife to Lyſander.
Lelia Cozen to Juliana.
Aemilia Miſtriſs to Lyſander.
Nurſe.
Lucia Servant to Aemilia.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: BUT that I know thee honeſt, I could not gueſs thou had'ſt a leſs deſign, than the betraying of this Town of Venice to the Grand Seignior.

sp.speaker: Ped.
sp.p: Or, ſince thou haſt ſuch an opinion of my honeſty, what do'ſt thou think of the retaking Candy?

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: In earneſt Pedro, thou haſt been as muſing this two hours, as a Polititian would be thought to be, when he thinks of juſt nothing; ſometimes you ſtand croſs arm'd, or biting of your nails; by and by nod, as if it was concluded: then on the ſudden ſcratch your head, as if ſome prodigious accident had ruin'd the conqueſt of the Indies.

sp.speaker: Ped.
sp.p: I am pleaſed it affords you mirth Antonio.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: What a Divel ayl'ſt man? if it be want of Wench or Money, (as I'me ſure thou can'ſt have no other cauſe of Melancholy) thou haſt lived long enough, one would think, to purchaſe confidence to tell thy Friend.

sp.speaker: Ped.
sp.p:
Thou'rt ſure to gueſs right, without being thought a Conjurer, nay you might have left one of them out too, for
Heaven ſend me money, and i'le never throw a way a thought, on any thing that's Woman; whilſt I know how to purchaſe them from a Ducat upwards.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: But it may be you are grown particular; I have known as brawny a Donn as your Worſhip, that has ſhrunk to the thinneſs of a Bul-ruſh, in leſs than two months time, for this thing cal'd Woman, that you talk of.

sp.speaker: Ped.
sp.p: Certainly thou haſt a better opinion of my underſtanding; particularly as the world goes now? Why Antonio, I tell thee, I will ſooner turn Pimp to a Suburb Bawdy Houſe, where there is nothing to be got, but blows, dead Wine, and the Pox: or Hermit, and forſwear the ſight of them, another extream, and as great a puniſhment, as —

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: Not ſo fierce, good Pedro, it muſt be money then.

sp.speaker: Ped.
sp.p: Yes faith, I was thinking, ſince my Father will not be ſo civil as to dye, what I ſhall do to live.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: He begins to grow a little rude now, that's the truth on't, I had one, thank my Fortune, that came to his Eſtate betimes, kept it till his Leaſe of one and twenty Years was run out, and never thought good to renew.

sp.speaker: Ped.
sp.p: That was kind, but mine's fourſcore, yet thinks as little of Death, as he did at fifteen: and o' my conſcience is as far from it; nay that that vexes me I can't reſt for his rules of temperance, and I know not what, and how he lived when he was a young man.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: Pox o' their Morals, when they are once paſt pleaſures themſelves, they envy us. They ne're conſider ſhould we all live, as they do now, the World would be undone, I tell thee Pedro, if it were not for this debauchery, that kicks up our heels in convenient time, it would not hold half of us.

sp.speaker: Ped.
sp.p: It would be pleaſant, but to hear what cunning contrivances I had to live in my Melancholy fit.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: Will you give me leave to gueſs? I'le lay my life gaming was the firſt propoſal.

sp.speaker: Ped.
sp.p:
Right, and concluded on, till I conſidered there was never a Scriveners Clerk, or Taylors Prentice about the
Town, but underſtood the trade; nay more, the very VVomen get it, and cheat with as much confidence as a Hec. that has but one ſtake left, ſo that deſign was ruin'd: my next was a Souldiers Life.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: The certain retreat of a broken Gamſter.

sp.speaker: Ped.
sp.p: But methoughts it was a little undecent for a man of my Quality, to walk the Street with one Leg, it may be never an Arm, and half a Noſe.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: Thou never thinkeſt how people would be concern'd for thee; one that ſo proper a Gentleman ſhould not be able to carry his Drink to his Head, the Women that your dancing was ſpoiled; beſides the Honor Man.

sp.speaker: Ped.
sp.p: Pox on't, That ſignifies juſt as much as Peoples Pitty, when one's certain of hanging: I'le have none on't: next I was for Poetry.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: Why what could put that into thy Head? that's the high way to Beggary.

sp.speaker: Ped.
sp.p: Not as the World goes now: Beſides, believe me, it is an eaſie Trade to one that underſtands a modern language or two, and will tranſlate.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: Nay hee muſt rime too, or the Ladies wil nere be pleas'd.

sp.speaker: Ped.
sp.p: Phu! That's but a weeks practice at Crambo, and once obtain'd ſaves us pains: for 'tis impoſſible to write non-ſence in't, ſome few long words, and half a ſcore ſentences out of Seneca's Tragedies, make an Heroick Poet.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: Come, thou haſt more wit than to think on't, never trouble thy ſelf, thou ſhalt want nothing whilſt thy Father lives; and when he dyes, I know it all ſecure.

sp.speaker: Ped.
sp.p: You are ſtill my Friend. That that vext me was to ſee that Rogue Piſauro, thrive by Air, wear his Jewels, variety of Cloths, keep his Lacquais, Horſes, play as deep as any man, and all this out of nothing.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: It muſt be ſome Woman, the little Rogues are grown ſo loving ſince theſe Wars, and want of men, that they begin to take it ill to be courted, and provide for themſelves.

sp.speaker: Ped.
sp.p: I could nere diſcover't, he's as private as a Confeſſor.

sp.speaker: Ant
sp.p: And upon the ſame account, for he gets money to conceal her vices: nay your Confeſſor is like him too in this, that he ſeldome hides the Womens faults, but in the ſame time he ſaves his own credit. But if it be a Woman, much good may it do him, I ſhall never envy him.

sp.speaker: Ped.
sp.p: Nor I, He had better thraſh, or be chain'd to the Gallyes.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: No more, here he is.

sp.speaker: Piſ.
sp.p: Save ye Gallants, I interrupt you.

sp.speaker: Ped.
sp.p: No Piſauro, we were juſt now gueſſing how thou did'ſt to live.

sp.speaker: Piſ.
sp.p: Faith Gentlemen ye are both my Friends, but we Chymiſts always conceal our great ſecret by which we thrive.

sp.speaker: Ped.
sp.p: Heaven ſend the Furnace where you make your gold, don't prove too hot for you.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: But why in this Garb? thou uſeſt to outſhine the Sun.

sp.speaker: Piſ.
sp.p: I am ſorry Gentlemen you have hit upon two Queſtions, I muſt be ſo uncivil as not to anſwer; but hereafter when things grow ripe..

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: There needs no excuſe Piſauro.

sp.speaker: Piſ.
sp.p: Your deſign goes forward with Pacheco?

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: Yes, yes I intend to carry Pedro thither,

sp.speaker: Piſ.
sp.p: And 'tis odds but I'le bring a Friend.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: Doſt think the Women will come in?

sp.speaker: Piſ
sp.p: Nere fear't they'l not ſtand out at any thing that makes for pleaſure.

sp.speaker: Ped.
sp.p: Theſe are myſteries Gentlemen.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: I'le unriddle all as we go.

sp.speaker: Piſ.
sp.p: Wee'l all meet anon, for the preſent I muſt leave you, and to a patient, though I think he is paſt cure.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: What's his Diſeaſe prethee, that thou art turn'd Quack?

sp.speaker: Ped.
sp.p: The Gentile one i'le warrant you, he cures that by his own experience.

sp.speaker: Piſ.
sp.p: No Faith worſe, he's taken o'th' ſudden with a love frenzy, and runs mad for a Wench.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: Pox on him, get him one then.

sp.speaker: Piſ.
sp.p: That will not do, I have offer'd him as fair as any one, but he is come to his Sonnets, and Serenades, ſighs and walks with his Hat over his Eyes in deep meditation of doggrell love verſes, calls her by fine Romantick names, ſometimes ſhe is Celia fair, then Phyllis, Amarillis, Clelia, and the Devil and all, but her right name, and that I am now going to learn.

sp.speaker: Ped.
sp.p: Prethee give him a little Ratsbain, or ſome cold Poyſon to cool his pluck; in love; I thought the World had learn't more witt above this 12 month.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: May we know the man?

sp.speaker: Piſ.
sp.p: I'le try but one Medicine more, and if that cure not, deliver him over to be baited: In the mean time if you chance to gueſs, pray conceal it till the game grows hot. Gallants adieu.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p:
Adieu
• iſauro. Come Pedro you won't fail.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.p: I wiſh ſhe were return'd, for I'me impatient till I hear ſome news, Heaven ſend ſhee meet him, and me rid of this fond Husband. I am as weary of him, as a VVoman can be of a Man, ſhe has married for money; I think I hear her.
Oh Lelia did you find him? and will he come?

sp.speaker: Lel.
sp.p: Yes Madam,

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.p: But art ſure he ſaid ſo? for thou art ſo apt to forget.

sp.speaker: Lel.
sp.p: As ſure Madam as that you long for his coming.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.p: Did'ſt remember the hour too?

sp.speaker: Lel.
sp.p: Lord Madam what makes you ſo miſtruſtful? I did, if you'le have me ſwear —

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.p: No I believe thee, prithee Cozen pardon me, and think what a ſorment 'tis to want the thing we love: Alas, now 'tis a whole long VVeek ſince I ſaw him: and beſides, all the while to be troubled with a doating Husband, would make any body impatient.

sp.speaker: Lel.
sp.p: Is kindneſs troubleſome? I thought no VVoman had complain'd on that ſide.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.p: O more then any thing, from one I cannot love.

sp.speaker: Lel.
sp.p: Pray Madam why did you marry then?

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.p: Poor innocent, do'ſt think that love's the only cauſe? there are a thouſand ſtronger Lelia, that's the very laſt, in any VVomans thoughts, that's wiſe.

sp.speaker: Lel.
sp.p: Pray inſtruct me then, it may be my fortune one day.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.p: I will and dare with confidence ſince I know thee private. Before I married people flatter'd me, or elſe they thought me fair, and that little beauty Lelia, was the greateſt of my Fortune.

sp.speaker: Lel.
sp.p: and truſt me Madam, a very great one too.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.p: As it was, it proved of ſtrength to tempt Lyſander, who was, and ſtill continues, one of the richeſt Merchants of the Town: my Parents thought the Match ſo great, that it vvas in vain for me to ſeem unvvilling: to be ſhort, I married him, but not for love Cozen, but to maintain my Dear Piſauro, vvho long before had ranſackt all my Virgin Treaſure, and ſtill enjoys my heart.

sp.speaker: Lel.
sp.p: I ſhall endeavour to learn Madam.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.p: Truſt me Lelia, no vvay's ſo direct to Miſery as to marry one you love. Love added to a Husbands povver, makes him perfect Tyrant; now let him do or ſay his pleaſure, all's indifferent.

sp.speaker: Lel.
sp.p: But is it not as much trouble Madam, to doat on your Gallant?

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.p: No Lelia, He has dependance on me, and all my happineſs is, I know his fortune's low; Oh! that he were but here once deareſt Piſauro.

sp.speaker: Lel.
sp.p: Here's your Husband Madam.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.p: Then I have a new Trade.

sp.speaker: Lyſ.
sp.p: Come Deareſt, I muſt take leave; what weeping? Thou haſt too much love.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.p: If I had thought I could have loved ſo well, I never ſhould have married ſure, ſcarce a Week but I am left to miſery and ſolitude, methinks I could curſe him that e're invented your profeſſion.

sp.speaker: Lel.
sp.p: Brave Woman thou ſhalt inſtruct all our Sex.

sp.speaker: Lyſ.
sp.p: Chear up deareſt, 'tis but for a few days, and i'le return, and love ſtill more, if poſſible.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.p: A day's an age to be from one I love, nay my mind give's me, you'le nere come agan, ſtay but one day.

sp.speaker: Lel.
sp.p: Heaven ſend he does not take her at her word.

sp.speaker: Lyſ.
sp.p: Fond Rogue, my word's engag'd, I cannot for a World.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.p: No you'le nere do any thing I ask you, ſtay but one hour, come prethee do, let this beg for me.

sp.speaker: Lel.
sp.p: Rarely acted, ſhe might deceive an Angel.

sp.speaker: Lyſ.
sp.p: Why if I ſhould thou'lt be the ſame then, and truſt me, my time is gone, nothing in the World ſhould tempt me from thee, but my credit, prethee Dear be patient.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.p: I have no other remedy, you are always t • us cruel, if you find me ſick, or dead, when you return, it will never trouble you.

sp.speaker: Lyſ.
sp.p: Come prethee be not ſo unkind, thou know'ſt I love thee, thou mak'ſt me weep to hear thee talk thus.

sp.speaker: Lel.
sp.p: Loving Cuckold! you would have cauſe, if you knew all.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.p: VVell if we muſt part for ever.

sp.speaker: Lyſ.
sp.p: I tell thee 'tis but a day or two.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.p: Farewel, Heaven proſper you, I muſt have the laſt look.

sp.speaker: Lyſ.
sp.p: No prethee go, or elſe you hinder me. Lelia wait on your Miſtreſs.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.p: One kiſs more, I'me all obedience, and then —

sp.speaker: Lyſ.
sp.p: Adieu deareſt.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.p: One look more. VVas't not rarely acted Lelia?

sp.speaker: Lel.
sp.p: To the life Madam.

sp.speaker: Lyſ.
sp.p: She's gone, and faith now I begin to think my ſelf a VVretch, to abu • e her thus. How eaſily their good nature is deceived? • oor doating fool! I dare ſwear ſhe loves me, then why ſhould I diſſemble thus with her? but hang't let her go, ſhe's but a VVife, and that's enough to fully all her worth. I'le to Emilia and there forget her: if I can get looſe, I may return a day or two the ſooner for this kindneſs.
sp.l: But when a Miſtreſs draws, a VVife muſt wait.
Your Fiſhes alwaies chooſe the freſheſt bait.

sp.speaker: Lel
sp.p: He's gone Madam, He had a grievous conflict betwixt love, and buſineſs, talkt a little to himſelf, gave a kind look or two this way, and Exit.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.p: A fair riddance, Poor Fool▪ now he's as ſecure of my love, as he is of being Cuckold. VVell men may talk of their wiſdom, conduct of affairs, &c. but this one VVomans vertue of diſſembling, out-weighs them all Lelia.

sp.speaker: Lel.
sp.p: True Madam, were we all as great proficients as your ſelf.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.p: 'Tis but getting a husband to Practice on, and thou'lt ſoon learn. How do I look to day Cozen?

sp.speaker: Lel.
sp.p: Tempting fair.

sp.speaker: Iul.
sp.p: I would be dreſt to all advantages, for every time I meet Piſauro, methinks I make a new conqueſt. Prethee what did he ſay to thee?

sp.speaker: Lel.
sp.p: Hee talk't ſomething of a Reformation was deſign'd very much for our advantage, I did not well underſtand him, but you'l here all anon.

sp.speaker: Iul.
sp.p:
I wiſh▪ he were here once, is't not the hour yet Lelia •
I'le meet him, if he comes not quickly, if we chance to miſs, he has the key, and knows where to expect me.

sp.speaker: Lel.
sp.p: Hee'l be here Madam preſently, pray be patient.

sp.speaker: Iul.
sp.l: To me even time it ſelf does ſlowly move,
There's no ſuch thing as patience in Love.

sp.speaker: Cam.
sp.p: Mariana, Iſmena, hey days! go ſeek'em out.

sp.speaker: Serv.
sp.p: They'r not within, Sir.

sp.speaker: Cam.
sp.p: Not within Sir? This 'tis! Women? I had rather have 40 Cats to look after; and they all wild too, great, wild, Hee Cats. I've ſeen Tygers, Lyons, Wolves coopt up, and tam'd: But let any man prove to me of his own knowledg, two Women that were ſo, and i'le believe all Mandevile. O' my conſcience I had all bedlams put together in me, when I got theſe girles, they make nothing of creeping through Key holes.

sp.speaker: Ser.
sp.p: They'r only gone to Church Sr.

sp.speaker: Cam.
sp.p: To Church Sr? what have women to do at Church Sr? can't they ſay their Prayers at home, or let them quite alone, and mind their needles? I tell thee there ne're comes any good of theſe holy pretences; were I young I'de as ſoon marry one out of the ſtewes as one of theſe religious gadders: and the truth on't is it comes much to one, for they meet with Prieſts at both places. Where's Pacheco?

sp.speaker: Serv.
sp.p: Abroad Sr.

sp.speaker: Cam.
sp.p: There's a youth too, hopeful enough till this curſed voyage: if any man longs to ſpoile a ſon, let him ſend him into England with an Embaſſadour. They are all mad there, and hated the very true Religion, becauſe of Nunnerys and Covents, that confin'd People to Sobriety and Chaſtity. I have a hopeful brood; would any thing but the down-right divel had'em.

So, are you come gypſyes? not a word, I've rayl'd my ſelf weary at preſent, get you in, I'le but take a turn i'th'
gallery, to recover a little, and you ſhall have it with a vengeance.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: What ſhall we do ſiſter, my Father's ſtrangly angry?

sp.speaker: Ism.
sp.p: Why e'ne go abroad again, and run for't, or let him talk out his talk, hee's old and quickly out of breath.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: We women are moſt miſerable creatures ſiſter, brought up at firſt by ſome ſevere Parent, or kinſwoman; and when we grow moſt ſenſible of bondage, deliver'd over to the tyranny of a cruel husband.

sp.speaker: Ism.
sp.p: Or clap't into a nunnery to ſpend our lives in thinking, and contemplation, though I perſwade my ſelf there's little of religion in't: but from the ſmall remembrance we have of men, ſcratch their pictures on the walls, and wiſh: and the firſt opportunity we have of being ſick make uſe of the confeſſor.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: Thou'rt a wild wench, will nothing tame thee?

sp.speaker: Ism.
sp.p: 'Twould make a dog wild to be tyed up thus, I wonder we can never muſter courage up for to rebell. I have read of women that have been famous for't, and I'm perſwaded I my ſelf have courage enough to be a general.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: My Brother talkes of ſome deſign he has, I wiſh he would compleat it once.

sp.speaker: Ism.
sp.p: Were I but a man I'de make my ſelf renown'd in the womens quarrel, work them all deliverance; and then ſhare the beſt of them.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: 'Tis the mens intereſt to keep us thus enclos'd Iſmena.

sp.speaker: Iſm.
sp.p: None but but a few elder brothers that are husbands Mariana, I dare ſwear were it once propoſed the young rogues would dye in our defence, 'twould make their addreſſes cheap and eaſy, vvhen as novv twenty fees can ſcarcely purchaſe a good look, vvhich falls hard upon the younger brothers. You'r Melancholy Siſter.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: I dread my fathers anger, and the very thoughts of liberty torment me vvorſe, then this impriſonment. Would my Brother vvould come home once, that vve might hear the nevvs.

sp.speaker: Iſm.
sp.p: Dread! I'me aſham'd to hear you name it, let's in and laug • , and vveary out this tyranny.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: 'Tis thy mirth that keeps me ſtill alive.

sp.speaker: Iſm.
sp.p: Come vvench,
sp.l: Our bodyes by a father are confin'd,
But there's no man can rule a vvomans mind.

div.head: Scena Quarta.

sp.speaker: Emi.
sp.p: No news of Lyſander?

sp.speaker: Lu.
sp.p: No Madam.

sp.speaker: Emi.
sp.p: I have not loſt my beauty yet, the ſame luſtre ſparkles in my E • es; and youth ſits ſmiling on my cheeks: the ſame brisk heat runs through my veins, and makes me warm, and active in my love. Then why ſhould he grow cold? Five days and not ſee me? 'tis very ſtrange! He's too wiſe to have the dotage of a wife ſeize him. No, 'tis another love grown happy by my ruin. I'le find out ſome new way to ſound him, for 'tis fixt. My youth muſt not be loſt in this indifference. Lucia bid them bring me in a Chair and Table, and do you fetch me the Prayer-book lyes in my cloſet.

sp.speaker: Luci.
sp.p: The Play-book Madam?

sp.speaker: Emi.
sp.p: No the Prayer-book, are you Deaf?

sp.speaker: Luci.
sp.p: You'd better have the other Madam, that will but make you melancholy.

sp.speaker: Emi.
sp.p: Goe I ſay, it may be I reſolve to be ſo.

sp.speaker: Luci.
sp.p: I ſhall have a ſad trade on't if it comes to this once. I wonder who invented theſe grave Books! or ever taught any of our profeſſion to read them, I'me ſure they'r very much out of our calling.

sp.speaker: Emi.
sp.p: It ſhall be ſo, and if this fail, I'le find ſome other way to live; there are more kind men than one.

div.stage: Enter Lucia, gives her the Book.

sp.speaker: Lucia.
sp.p: Here Madam, but I hope you are not in earneſt.

sp.speaker: Emi.
sp.p: Peace Baggage, and if Lyſander come, tell him I'me not to be diſturb'd.

div.stage: Sits down and turns over the Book.

sp.speaker: Luci.
sp.p: Since you are ſo ſerious, you ſhall have none of my Company: I'le e'ne go ſing a brisk ſong or two i'th' next room, and bleſs the firſt man that comes to put you out of this humor.
Oh here's Lyſander, then I muſt run for't.

sp.speaker: Emi.
sp.p: He's come, now all that's woman help me to diſſemble. Yet I can find no Prayer that's fit for me. Sure never any woman was ſo wicked.

sp.speaker: Lys.
sp.p: Come Emelia throw away thy book, and fly to my embraces, thou need'ſt not ſtudy any new charms. Come let me ſee what 'tis that tempts thee thus: ſome ſmutty Novells on my life. How's this? A Prayer book! I ſhould ſooner expect to ſee the French King turn Calviniſt than to find thee in this poſture. What ſad affliction has brought thee to this miſery? Haſt ſpotted thy new gown? loſt thy little dog? or doſt want a new faſhion'd pair of Pendants? Prithee tell me.

sp.speaker: Emi.
sp.p: No, No, Sr. None of theſe. But I have ſpotted all my life, loſt my innocence which you have rob'd me off; and want a new heart▪

sp.speaker: Lys.
sp.p: Hey day! turn'd Canter? this becomes thee worſe than fine dreſs, and youthful cloths an old woman: There's ſcarce a Nun will talk thus through a grate.

sp.speaker: Emi.
sp.p: But I ſhall when I'me there (as I reſolve I will) and if I can, teach you repentance.

sp.speaker: Lys.
sp.p: Pox o' this wheadle, I ſee through it, and will cure her by one as extravagant.

sp.speaker: Emi.
sp.p: It is but Juſt I help to waſh away your guilt, who have been the unlucky cauſe.

sp.speaker: Lyſ.
sp.p: Now for my trade. Oh Emilia from this minute I'me happy: give me your hand, my bloud's obedient; and I can touch thee now with as chaſt thoughts, as Virgins pray.

sp.speaker: Emi.
sp.p: If this be real, I'me undone, but I muſt on.

sp.speaker: Lyſ.
sp.p: Methinks I loath my former life. Oh could vve but call it back Emilia.

sp.speaker: Emi.
sp.p: Then vve vvere bleſt indeed. But ſince that cannot be, I'le double all my Oriſons, and that way make up my arrears: And never ſpeak, or think of man, but vvhen I put up prayers for you, O Lyſander.
—Hang me if I can hold for laughing: if I make a good end of this, if I ever undertake to Preach again, may I turn Nun in earneſt.

sp.speaker: Lyſ.
sp.p: She will out-do me; they have th' advantage of a voyce for whining, but I'le try. I'le to a cloyſter too, for 'tis but juſt the reſidue of life be ſpent in puniſhing this too much pamper'd fleſh. There in our ſeveral cells we'll faſt, and watch, and waſh away our guilt, and when we're fit to dye remove to heaven. Oh Emilia!

sp.speaker: Emi.
sp.p: This is counterfeit too, but how to come off I can't imagine. Well, dear Lyſander (for now I dare call thee ſo) ſince our deſigns agree, let's time our Prayers, that Heaven may hear us both together.

sp.speaker: Lyſ.
sp.p: We'll riſe before the morn.

sp.speaker: Emi.
sp.p: Out-watch the pale-faced moon.

sp.speaker: Lyſ.
sp.p: Nor eat to ſatisfie our appetite, but lengthen out our lives for our devotion.

sp.speaker: Emi.
sp.p: We will not drink, but what our tears have ſeaſon'd.

sp.speaker: Lyſ.
sp.p: Nor ſleep.

sp.speaker: Emi.
sp.p: Nor think.

sp.speaker: Lyſ.
sp.p: Nor dream.

sp.speaker: Emi.
sp.p: Nor live.

sp.speaker: Lyſ.
sp.p: Nor any thing but —

sp.speaker: Emi.
sp.stage: They both burſt out a laughing.
sp.p: I can hold no longer.

sp.speaker: Lyſ.
sp.p: Nor I by heaven. You idle rogue, could you imagine I could think thee in earneſt?

sp.speaker: Emi.
sp.p: I was once half afraid that you was, till I conſider'd how ill it became you.

sp.speaker: Lyſ.
sp.p: Now what amends for all this? Will you never leave this jealouſie?

sp.speaker: Emi.
sp.p: You ſhall find that within. I did it only for to try you after your abſence.

sp.speaker: Lyſ.
sp.p: No more of theſe tricks, there needs none, I am as fond as ever, come let's in and enjoy our ſelves, and ſome twenty years hence, we may venture on ſuch a diſcourſe in earneſt.

div.head: SCENA I.

sp.speaker: Piſ.
sp.p: YEt you reſolve to have this wench?

sp.speaker: Lea.
sp.p: Why I'me ſure thou wouldſt not have me dye, if it were only to ſave the trouble of praying for me.

sp.speaker: Piſ.
sp.p: Faith it would put me a little out of my road, that's the truth on't; but why muſt you needs dye? Thou haſt not ſeen her above twice, and that at Church too: if you had been at your appointment you might have avoided ſuch temptations; for my part I'me reſolv'd to keep out of harms way.

sp.speaker: Lea.
sp.p: Away you're profane.

sp.speaker: Piſ.
sp.p: Prithee ſtay till thy Saint's Canoniz'd, before thou ſay ſo; do you think it religion to kneel ſquinting at your miſtriſs, two or three hours with your beads in your hands; and only caſt up your eyes, becauſe ſhe's i'th' gallery above you?

sp.speaker: Lea.
sp.l: Heaven made ſuch beauty for to be ador'd.

sp.speaker: Piſ.
sp.l: And ſhe'l make uſe of it for to be whor'd
sp.p: Why don't you go on? I thought you had a coppy of verſes on it. Heaven made &c. I ſhall believe you are in love, when once you talk your ſublime nonſence. Heaven, Beauty, Fate, Adoration, Sun, Divinity and a few ſuch words will make thee Poet too, and then thou'rt fit to court a Queen.

sp.speaker: Lea.
sp.p:
I was bewitch't to tell you, I knew you vvould but
mock at my misfortunes; I ſhould hardly ſerve Piſauro ſo.

sp.speaker: Piſ.
sp.p: Misfortunes do you call it? will you make me believe women can run through thee, like lightning, and ſet what brand upon a heart they pleaſe? Let me be thy Doctor and preſcribe thee two or three of my infallible cures againſt this witchcraft of love. Feed high. Wench diſcreetly. And go to bed with a jolly cup. Probatum eſt —'tis as infallible as the Jeſuites po • der for a Quartan.

sp.speaker: Lea.
sp.p: I ſee I muſt find ſome other friend to help me in my affaires. Adieu.

sp.speaker: Piſ.
sp.p: I'le be ſerious. By my troth I had ſuch a qualm came over me once, 'twas troubleſome, and laſted about a quarter of an hour, but ſince a ſhe friend of mine taught me to draw the humor downward, I'me free.

sp.speaker: Lea.
sp.p: I have no patience to bear this fooling.

sp.speaker: Piſ.
sp.p: I have done, pray pardon me; but which way do'ſt thou intend for to obtain her? The old man keeps her with more care, than he does his gold; He cut of a dog's ears t'other day, to ſearch for lettters: And has a gun ready charged to kill pidgeons, for fear they ſhould be Carryers: He ſwounds at the ſight of a poſt, or any thing that runs of errands.

sp.speaker: Lea.
sp.p: This difficulty makes me need thy help. I know thee expert in all the tricks of women; art read in their winks and nods, canſt tell how to anſwer with a ſhrug or ſigh, knowſt how to wheadle Chamber Maids, and make love to old nurſes. Prethee be ſerious and adviſe me.

sp.speaker: Piſ.
sp.p: Now I ſee thou art in earneſt, I can, and will Leandro.

sp.speaker: Lea.
sp.p: But how dear Piſauro?

sp.speaker: Piſ.
sp.p: Why thus: old Camillo, Father to thy Iſmena, has a ſon lately return'd from England, whither he went with our Embaſſador.

sp.speaker: Lea.
sp.p: This way I can foreſ • e no hopes.

sp.speaker: Piſ.
sp.p:
Yes very much. You knew him humorſome, and conceited before his voyage; but this has added to him all the fopperies of that Nation, which they borrow from the French: ſo that he's the ſtrangeſt piece of Fantaſtickneſs
that can make droll for a play: in ſhort he is a meer ſinging ſwitching Fopp.

sp.speaker: Lea.
sp.p: Still you amaze me.

sp.speaker: Piſ.
sp.p: Suffer me. Amongſt the reſt of the Engliſh cuſtomes 'tis one, and faith almoſt the only one that pleaſes me, to allow all poſſible freedom to their women. This he reſolves to bring up in Venice, and will in ſpight of his father, begin with his own ſiſters. There is a Royal ſociety of us, call'd the Reformers. Doſt thou yet underſtand me?

sp.speaker: Lea.
sp.p: Yes, this ſounds like ſomething.

sp.speaker: Piſ.
sp.p: We'l admit thee into the number, and then ſhift for thy ſelf. I muſt leave you, and to the buſineſs that concerns my life (as I was telling you) my little Merchant adventures, Oh! 'tis the kindeſt thing, ſo like matrimony, and yet no trouble. Now vve talk of reforming, could you all thrive like me, and leave off the damn'd trade of keeping vvenches, and let them keep you, 'tvvould be a happy vvorld.

sp.speaker: Lea.
sp.p: But I'me for neither, I'me for the honeſt vvay of marrying.

sp.speaker: Piſ.
sp.p: Heaven forbid, but that ſomebody ſhould like that dull trade: for if there vvere no vvives, there vvould be no husbands to rob to maintain us younger Brothers.

sp.speaker: Lea.
sp.p: You ſtill keep your old humor; but vvhy no better dreſt man?

sp.speaker: Piſ.
sp.p: I'le tell you; I ſerve her, as the vvenches uſed to ſerve me; alvvays pretend to vvant ſomething: thou ſhalt ſee me as glorious as the day at our next meeting.

sp.speaker: Lea.
sp.p: Stay, vvho are theſe?

sp.speaker: Piſ.
sp.p: Antonio and Pedro, tvvo of the ſociety: I'le admit you preſently.

sp.speaker: Ped.
sp.p: Thou'rt a rare rogue: Hovv the Divel could'ſt thou find Rhetorick enough to vvheadle him to this?

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p:
He did it himſelf Sir. And tells me in England, 'tis thought honorable to bring their ſiſters acquainted, as they call it, I believe ſome faſhionable name for Pimping. 'Tis ordinary there to do it for a kins woman, and that may ſave a portion.
Heaven ſend them good faces, and they never need work for their livings. Oh 'tis. —

sp.speaker: Piſ.
sp.p: Save you Gallants, how does the Society go forward?

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: With full ſail, Piſauro.

sp.speaker: Piſ.
sp.p: Shall I beg admiſſion for my friend here?

sp.speaker: Ped.
sp.p: Leandro! The only man we wiſhed; but he muſt be ſworn according to form.

sp.speaker: Lea.
sp.p: Your Servant Gentlemen, I ſhall willingly paſs any ceremony.

sp.speaker: Piſ.
sp.p: They are eaſie, only an oath or two to ſwallow, and they are gilded.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: Lay your hand upon the book. 'Tis Ovid de arte amandi, and begin. You ſhall ſwear, to the uttermoſt of your power to reform Venice according to the Pattern of Enland in manners and diſcipline; and that you will, without reſpect of perſons, endeavour the extirpation of Tyranny, that is, the government of Husbands and Fathers, by Siſters, Aunts, Nurſes, and all other officers depending upon that Uſurpation. And that you will with the ſame ſincerity root out the ſpreading errors of Vizards, Maſques, Veyles, Padlocks, both for the reſtoring of loſt pleaſures to your ſelf, and the freedom of the diſtreſſed Ladys.
So help you Cupid.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: So, now you are a ſworn Brother, we need keep nothing ſecret.

sp.speaker: Piſ.
sp.p: Where's our Grand-maſter Pacheco?

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: I left him with his Tutor, the Engliſh man, contriving which way to get his Siſters out of Priſon.

sp.speaker: Lea.
sp.p: That's the Engliſh man, I warrant, that pretends ſo much to Poetry and breeding; and cenſures all the old Authors, with as much Authority as if he had been their School-maſter.

sp.speaker: Piſ.
sp.p: The ſame; if he gets but the upper end of a Table at an Ordinary, you ſhall have him run them over as faſt, as a Dutch-man tells money.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p:
Sometimes he pretends to Plays too, and then he damns French, Spaniſh, and Italian in a wind, yet ſteals out
of the very worſt of them. He would be thought to have a little kindneſs for an Author or two of his own Nation, but will be ſure to ruin their reputation too, with ſome exception or other, before he leaves them.

sp.speaker: Lea.
sp.p: Does he ever write himſelf?

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: Yes, Yes; but as all your profeſt Criticks do, damnably ill: To tell you the truth (for I have made it my buſineſs to underſtand him) the fellow has wit, but broke with driving a trade too big for his ſtock; and when Pacheco took him in, all he had to ſubſiſt on, was confidence, and the favour of two or three fopps.

sp.speaker: Ped.
sp.p: Faith he's bravely fitted with a Maſter.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: 'Tis very pleaſant to hear him talk of the advantages of this Reformation, his Lectures of Repartes, Converſe, Regales, and an hundred more unintelligible fopperies.

sp.speaker: Ped.
sp.p: To end, he has order'd us to expect him at the old place, where we ſhall hear the Reſult of all.

sp.speaker: Piſ.
sp.p: There you may expect me then an hour hence.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: But how ſhall we find a Miſtreſs for Pacheco?

sp.speaker: Ped.
sp.p: —Why faith I have a wench I grow ſomething weary of, he ſhall have her.

sp.speaker: Lea.
sp.p: No, that's too cruel.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: What think you of my boy finely dreſt? The rogue has a ſmooth face, and ſings well.

sp.speaker: Piſ.
sp.p: Nor that neither. I have a Cozen witty and handſome, whoſe Fathers fortunes were ruin'd in our laſt wars at Candy: what if we ſet her up? ſhe may teach him wit.

sp.speaker: Ped.
sp.p: As you can agree. But prithee, now you talk of ſinging, let Leandro hear the ſong you made upon the Reformation.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: Sing boy.

lg.l: Beauty no longer ſhall ſuffer Eclipſe,
The power of thoſe eyes, or uſe of thoſe lips
Nor ſhall husband or Father repine.
We'el baniſh the ſtratagems us'd by the State
To keep the poor women in aw,
Henceforth they themſelves, ſhall rule their own fate
And deſire ſhall be to them a law.
Where in private we'el teach them the Myſteries of Love,
Till we the fond Scruple of honor remove,
And the end of our paſſion diſcover.
For each may be eas'd by her Lover.
Away with all things that ſound like to Laws,
Let the Formaliſts prate, the good old cauſe

sp.speaker: Lea.
sp.p: 'Tis a brisk deſign, and muſt needs take among the Ladies: but are the ſo free in England as you pretend?

sp.speaker: Ped.
sp.p: Freer than you can think Sir. 'Tis mortal ſin not to know what's what at fifteen.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: Fifteen! They have loſt time at that age; a Maiden-head at thirteen is as great a rarity in the country as a wolf; now and then in ſome village there may be ſome ugly Monſter, that holds out longer upon force, but —

sp.speaker: Piſ.
sp.p: In earneſt Leandro, the ſobereſt women there, have more freedom of diſcourſe and company, than we give to a ſtale Bawd, or an old Midwife at a Chriſtening: And yet the men ſo free from jealouſie, that you ma • as ſoon perſwade one of us to leave whoring, as them to believe their own eyes.

sp.speaker: Ped.
sp.p: Nay, they are ſo contrary to us, that a Vizard Maſque is a certain ſign of a free booter, and nothing makes them cover their faces but impudence.

sp.speaker: Lea.
sp.p: This muſt needs be the fortunate Iſland, people talk ſo much off.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: Now after all this, make it a matter of conſcience: conſider the neceſſity of this Reformation, and how damnably we have been wheadled b • theſe veiles of ours. After half a years attendance, and courting of ſome delicate ſhape, that would tempt a Hermit in the midſt of ſnow, to loſe all our expectation and compliment, and when we ſee the Divels face, be forced to fly, and croſs our ſelves for fear of blaſting.

sp.speaker: Piſ.
sp.p: 'Tis intolerable. I tell you I reſolve to ſpare no body, a Vizard ſha'n't paſs though it be following her Mother to the grave: nor any face be hid by a veil, though the woman be to do penance in a Church: The truth on't is, Gentlemen, there muſt be no mean, rank rebellion or nothing.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: At that I'me with you, and I know not but this may make us as famous, as inventing a new Religion.

sp.speaker: Ped.
sp.p: There's no queſtion. Thou art well read, 'tis but finding half a dozen places in our modern Reformers, to back us, and the buſineſs is done.

sp.speaker: Piſ.
sp.p: This deſign has ſo tickled me, that I have forgot my aſſignation. Leandro I leave you to be introduced by theſe Gentlemen.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: We'l all go.

sp.speaker: Piſ.
sp.p: My way lies here, I'le be with you preſently.

sp.l: Let your politick nodles debate
So our women be free,
'Tis nothing to him, to thee, or to me
Who governs the Church or the State.

div.stage:
Exeunt. Ant. Ped. Leandro.
as Piſauro is going out at the other door.

sp.speaker: Piſ.
sp.p: So my adventures begin already: though two to one be odds, I muſt board them; Heaven ſend they don't prove Fire-ſhips

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.p: 'Tis he.

sp.speaker: Piſ.
sp.p: Nay faith Madam, no paſſing this way without a ſmall Patley, and a kind look or two.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.p: Sure you'r ſome ſtranger you'r ſo rude, do you know you are in Venice, Sir?

sp.speaker: Piſ.
sp.p: Yes Madam, but I perceive you don't know the moſt conſiderable news of the place. How the Divel do you two come into theſe Vizards that have been out of faſhion theſe ſix hours?

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.p: What Sir? and the men are to wear them to cover bad faces, as the women did to ſave good ones?

sp.speaker: Piſ.
sp.p: Well ſaid Spitfire, come, unmaſque for fear I call yours in queſtion; for were you fair, you would be proud too, and we muſt hire you to keep it on.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.p: Like enough Sir, were the prize worth taking, but what ſhall I get by conquering you? You look as if you had nothing about you, but a Surgeons bill, and it may be a Taylours, which muſt be worn out with carrying in your pocket too, if it came home with your cloaths.

sp.speaker: Piſ.
sp.p: As I live ſhe g • eſſes all my treaſure within a Ducatoon: Oh for ſome ſuccor to relieve the forlorn hope. Aſide. Nay if you once turn wit, I'le ſwear you'r ugly; and now I look again I ſee your wall e • es, and gueſs the length of your noſe by the ſhape of your Maſque. Faith Madam, the men are beholden to you, that you take ſuch care not to fright them.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.p: Without you repent you ſhall pine for this, though it be ſpoke at random.

sp.speaker: Lelia.
sp.p: This is the ſtrangeſt beggar I ever heard Madam; but you uſe to be charitable, give him ſomething to put him into repair, the Gentlemen has been in a Storm.

sp.speaker: Piſ.
sp.p:
Do you begin to open too, you piſpot-emptier, you
muſt be ſuch by the old lace ſhoes, and reſpect you have to follow the faſhion at a diſtance.

sp.speaker: Lel.
sp.p: Marry come up! one had better be out of the faſhion, than out at the elbows.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.p: Methinks one of your complexion might light upon ſome wife, or eaſy fool that would buy her pleaſures at the price of perriwigs, or a new ſuit, you have had ill fortune Sir. Prithee Lelia help me to abuſe him.

sp.speaker: Piſ.
sp.p: Worſe and worſe ſhe knows me too: yet refuſe me, if (except this minute to Leandro) I ever told it ſo much as to my Confeſſor, but moſt of your women are witc • es.

sp.speaker: Lel.
sp.p: Or what do you think of a Gentleman Uſher? you have a good faſhionable face; and your Lady will ſee to bring your legs to a fit ſize.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.p: No, No; I tell you he ſcorns any thing of Service. The Ladies doat on him, 'tis ten to one, but that hee's juſt now ſent for, you ſee hee's dreſt for the purpoſe.

sp.speaker: Piſ.
sp.p: Pox on you both, for I have nothing left to ſay but curſes, and they ſhall be home: may you be both Padlock'd, chayn'd together, and turn'd upon a Common; or which is yet worſe, may you always gape for meat, and it be death for any man to feed you.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.p: Nay if you be ſo good at that, I'le have one for you too; may you have nothing to maintain you, but the favor of ſome woman, and ſhe grow weary and diſcard you.

sp.speaker: Piſ.
sp.p: Heaven forbid, that bites, I'de give all the world to ſee this Divel, and will before I go.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.p: Nay, never take the pains to ſtrive.

sp.speaker: Piſ.
sp.p: How! Juliana! Could you curſe with ſo much cruelty, when you knew me too?

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.p: Don't you deſerve it? how do you like my wall-eyes now?

sp.speaker: Piſ.
sp.p: Now you're cruel: Good faith I did not know thee, I was juſt coming.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.p: I have waited above this two hours, but you men when you once get a hank upon our affections, think you may do any thing.

sp.speaker: Piſ.
sp.p: By this you ſha'n't be angry. I have the pleaſan'ſt ſtory to tell you; come be pleaſed Lelia ſhall engage for me.

sp.speaker: Lel.
sp.p: Yes I have cauſe, you did not abuſe me?

sp.speaker: Piſ.
sp.p: Peace, I'le ſtop thy mouth with a husband Girle.

sp.speaker: Lel.
sp.p: Say you ſo? I have done.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.p: Well I'le try you once again, but if ever —I'le only go round and meet you, you have the key of the back door.

sp.speaker: Piſ.
sp.l: What fool will truſt himſelf to wind and waves?
When thus he reaps the fruit and trouble ſaves?
A Husband's factor for his wifes Gallant,
And till he break, the other nere can want.

sp.speaker: Pac.
sp.p: That was ſomething nigh it, but methinks I ha'n't the right fling yet. I'le try agen.

sp.speaker: Tut.
sp.p: I here you nickt it. Now for your Virtuoſo's Looking glaſs.

sp.speaker: Pac.
sp.stage: Pulls out a piece of poliſht mettal.)

sp.speaker: Tut.
sp.p: Right Sir, that expreſſes your deſign of promoting new experiments. You muſt obſerve it in every thing not ſo much as a tooth-picker, but muſt have ſomething extraordinary.

sp.speaker: Pac.
sp.p: Would not this ſhew genteel and modiſh in a Play-houſe?

sp.speaker: Tut.
sp.p: This and the managing • our comb will make you paſs for a Critick in the faſhion. The next thing you may practice is ſome few books, and then you are a wit too.

sp.speaker: Pac.
sp.p: That's the only thing I aim at; on good Tutor.

sp.speaker: Tut.
sp.p: When you come to a new Play, and know the Author is no fighter, and you may venture to abuſe him; firſt ſit grave and unconcern'd, and be ſure to caſt an eye upon ſome fam'd wit of the town, and take him for your pattern.

sp.speaker: Pac.
sp.p: But how if there be none there Tutor.

sp.speaker: Tut.
sp.p:
Why then if any thing takes in general you may venture
to ſmile a little: if only amongſt ſome few, and you imagine it not good, caſt a ſcornful look about you, as if you pittied their ignorance. Above all things commend nothing without ſome exception. Theſe few rules well obſerv'd, you'l be a ſtandard of carriage unto others.

sp.speaker: Pac.
sp.p: Nay, they almoſt take me for a wit already, I know all the Poets Chriſten names; and call Tom and Jack with as much confidence, as if I had been their God-father.

sp.speaker: Tut.
sp.p: That's well: There's very much in that. You may take occaſion to give them the familiar ſhrug, talk aloud, and ſwear, Tom the humour in thy laſt Prologue was high and new. Pox on thee for a rogue, thoul't grow famous. A whiſper now and then, with a great laugh after it does well.

sp.speaker: Pac.
sp.p: Did not you talk ſomething of a ſhrug? You promis'd to teach me the way of accoſting people, that's the word I think in England.

sp.speaker: Tut.
sp.p: Yes, mark▪ Firſt take notice of no body in bad cloaths, or poor, though it ſhould be your own Father come out of the country for to ſee you: or if you muſt needs ſpeak to him, withdraw, and after half a ſcore words return, and tell the company that a Tenant wants diſpatch, or a dependant on the family; and you'l be with them preſently.

sp.speaker: Pac.
sp.p: I ſha'n't forget this, 'tis ſo natural to me ever ſince I have been in England. I can't tell what to ſay to any one that wants a white wig, and a new ſuit.

sp.speaker: Tut.
sp.p: When you're nigh a perſon of honour, and one you think it a credit to be acquainted with, be ſure to turn and ſmile, though it be a ſecret hee's whiſpering to another, and you don't hear a word. This makes you be thought familiar, and a favorite at Court

sp.speaker: Pac.
sp.p: That's excellent, faith Tutor I'le remember I'le warrant you.

sp.speaker: Tut.
sp.p:
As for your Equals, your ſhrug, or ſhaking of the head, as if you had been at a debauch the night before, is creditable and modiſh. As to practice: Mounſieur Pacheco? ſhrugs. Come, how is't? ſhrugs What at ſome deep engagement
with the Ladies laſt night, or a tavern on my life. ſhrugs.

sp.speaker: Tut.
sp.p: That's right, and confirms him, that you drink and wench, things of more credit, as the world goes, than a Knight-hood, or the command of a Regiment.

sp.speaker: Pac.
sp.p: Incomparable Tutor! but no more, for fear I forget: beſides I fear they ſtay for us; and I would not hinder the Reformation, to be great Duke.

sp.speaker: Tut.
sp.l: In England, where each Writer ſhares the ſtakes,
The gains are ſmall, and one the other breaks.
But here alone without controul I rule,
His trade can't fail that's Tutor to a fool.

sp.speaker: Tutor.
sp.p: I Tell you truth Sir.

sp.speaker: Lyſ.
sp.p: Piſauro? the thing it ſelf does not ſo much perplex me, as that I'me over-reacht; and yet it cannot be; ſhe's all fondneſs.

sp.speaker: Tut.
sp.p: What greater ground can you propoſe for your ſuſpicion? Conſider Sir, had you the ſame deſign what other way is left to hide it? But I have done the office of a friend believed or not.

sp.speaker: Lyſ.
sp.p: This argument has convinced me, and ſince thou art ſo much my Friend, I'le tell you, I have the ſame deſign, and love a Miſtreſs more than twenty Wives, and by this very means conceal it from her. But People that pretend themſelves to cunning, ſeldom ſee through others. Doſt think he's there now?

sp.speaker: Tut.
sp.p: I'me ſure he was Sir within this half hour I ſee him enter.

sp.speaker: Lyſ.
sp.p: Then I will ſurprize them. I know ſhe can't expect me yet a day or two. I'le only diſpatch an houres buſineſs Gives him gold. and be with them. Pray accept of this acknowledgment, you're far from home and truſt me 'tis a real kindneſs. For had I found it out my ſelf I know not what a ſudden heat might drive me to. A little time to pawſe will make me unconcern'd.

sp.speaker: Tut.
sp.p: If this project chance to fail, within a day or two I'le find out one that ſhall be certain.

sp.speaker: Lyſ.
sp.p: Till my one eyes convince me I'le be ſtill the ſame. Adieu.

sp.speaker: Tut.
sp.p: Your Servant Sir. Thus far things go well, and here's a good reward. But let me think. This Gallant keeps his Miſtriſs too. That ſhall to Juliana. And ſince they are ſo much for Reformation I'le ſhow them one more of our Country tricks. The taking fees on both ſides.

div.head: ACT III. SCENE II.

sp.speaker: Ma.
sp.p: THis England muſt be a bleſſed place my Brother talks ſo much of it.

sp.speaker: Iſ.
sp.p: Would I were there; that I might be acquainted with theſe men, I have ſuch a tickling runs through me when I ſee them.

sp.speaker: Ma.
sp.p: And there it is commoner for them to go to a treat, than for us to go to Church; never a day but this Lords or that Knights Coach waits on you and hurrys you to a Play, thence into the Park, then there's ſuch perpetual Maſquerades and Balls, that 'tis Carnival all the year.

sp.speaker: Iſ.
sp.p: And here if we have a little liberty before Lent we are ſure to pine for't, ſo that the whole year ſcarce recruits us again.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: They have no ſuch thing there: they account it almoſt ſin not to eat fleſh when 'tis forbidden by the Church.

sp.speaker: Iſ.
sp.p: That's a life worth ſomething, I wonder why theſe old men live, ſure there they all dy when they're young, or elſe the women never knew their Fathers, for my part I wiſh I had never known mine: I'me ſure he's grievous troubleſome.

sp.speaker: Ma.
sp.p: Fie Iſmena conſider he is your Father.

sp.speaker: Iſ.
sp.p: Fie me no fies, Mariana, I vvonder vvho diſturbs his telling of money, or any thing he has a mind to: does he think becauſe he had the pleaſure to get us, vve are bound to be his Slaves? if he had not been my Father 'tis odds but ſomebody elſe vvould, I've heard them ſay my Mother vvas a handſome vvoman.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: Peace for ſhame and be content a vvhile, you knovv vvhat my Brother promiſed us to day.

sp.speaker: Iſ.
sp.p: I vviſh he vvould make his vvords good and bring them once. But I have a ſtrong fancy vve ſhall quarrel, for I have had a mind to every man I have ſeen yet.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: I vviſh it vvere come to that once, for I am grievous weary of working theſe vertuous Stories of conſtant wives.

sp.speaker: Iſ.
sp.p: Conſtant! thine I think's Penelope an old withered witch that was forced to ſpin ten years to earn money to pay her drudges with; and when ſhe had wearied them all out, ſent to ſeek her Husband; mine's Lucretia, it may be ſhe was vertuous but it would never grieve one to kill ones ſelf, ſo one was well raviſhed firſt.

sp.speaker: Ma.
sp.p: Now thou art ſtark mad.

sp.speaker: Iſ.
sp.p: Phu! we may ſay any thing amongſt our ſelves, if we did not talk merrily how ſhould we be able to live?

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: Heark, I hear my Father, Heaven ſend him in a better humor than vvhen he laſt left us.

sp.speaker: Iſ
sp.p: He'd beſt look to himſelf, for ſuch another Scold vvould cut off tvvo or three years at leaſt.

sp.speaker: Cam.
sp.p: So, this I like, if I ever catch you abroad again vvithout my leave, do you hear I'le have your legs tyed together.

sp.speaker: Iſm.
sp.p: We may ſometimes go to Church Sir.

sp.speaker: Cam.
sp.p: No, I'de rather have thee ſtay at home and be damn'd; I wonder what 'tis you do at Church? make mouths at ſome young fellow, who talks to you all the while on his beads. Come come, I know all your tricks and will have you ſtay at home; nor ſhall any come to ſee you, no not your Brother to tell you Stories of his England voyage: curſe on the Nation.

sp.speaker: Ma.
sp.p: Not my Brother Sir? this is too ſevere.

sp.speaker: Cam.
sp.p: No not your Brother Minks; you're like to come to good when you'l be inſtructing of your Father. Here Nurſe take the Keys, and give no more liberty than the two next rooms afford without my order.

sp.speaker: Nurſe.
sp.p: I warrant you Sir, I'le keep them cloſe.
Now Mrs. Iſmena I ſhall be even with you for all your f • umps.

sp.speaker: Iſm.
sp.p: Nay as long as you are with us we ſhall want no ſport, come Siſter help me to ſhake her to pieces.

sp.speaker: Nurſ.
sp.p: Will you murder me? Oh!

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: The other ſhake does it, I heard her bones rattle.

sp.speaker: Nurſ.
sp.p: Oh I am dead.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: You keep them cloſe you old toadſtool! thou art too ugly to be a Bawd.

sp.speaker: Iſm.
sp.p: She had been a Witch Siſter, but that the Divel loathed to ſuck her.

sp.speaker: Nurſ.
sp.p: When you are once in your pound I'le make you faſt for this, you ſha'n't ſo much as ſee a man this twelvemoneth, nay, I'le have your hands tied behind you, that you may not ſcratch where it itches.

sp.speaker: Iſm.
sp.p: That would be hard indeed Siſter.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: Leave your threats, or you know your old puniſhment: or what do you think of toſſing her in a blanquet? ſhe's ſo old and dry ſhe muſt be light.

sp.speaker: Iſm.
sp.p:
Excellent! if we had her in the Garden on a windy day 'twould be a ſure riddance; But now I think on't Siſter
we'l get ſome packthread and fly her as the boyes do a paper kite with a Candle and Lanthorn at her tayl. She'l make a rare Comet.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: 'Tis the beſt uſe of her, ſhe's like the picture of one of the Sibylls above in the Dining room, and this is the way to make her prophecy.

sp.speaker: Nurſ.
sp.p: Well Mrs. Percks this goes to your Father, with ſome improvement of my own.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: If you dare Keeks, we'l in and ſtudy a revenge.

sp.speaker: Iſm.
sp.p: Farewell Rattle, and be ſure to keep us cloſe.

div.stage: The old woman locks them in.

sp.speaker: Nurſ.
sp.p: So, if you will prate, Magpies, it ſhall be in a Cage. Theſe Gimcracks if they once come towards fifteen are ſo gameſome, there's no riding them without a curb, nay then 'tis ten to one but that they fling the firſt Adventurer out of the Saddle too. The Divel's in them I think, I'me ſure in my young days. But I'de as good ſtop I ſhall be tempted to lie elſe. The truth is I hate all young women that are fair and there's reaſon for't; if we old ones get a good look once a twelvemonth, be ſure the next young one that paſſes by robs us.

div.stage: Enter Pacheco, Pedro, Antonio, Leandro, and Tutor.

sp.speaker: Pac.
sp.p: Come Gentlemen, the old man's ſafe, enter, and think your ſelves in England: there we run about till we find the Ladies Chambers, ranſack every thing, and are never chid except it be for not ſtaying longer. What ſay you, Tutor?

sp.speaker: Tutor.
sp.p: He tells you truth Gallants, we help to dreſs and undreſs faith almoſt any thing; yet all the while as Vertuous as two Nuns. More, you'l find there is no other way but liberty to make us ſo.

sp.speaker: Lean.
sp.p: I'me glad to hear the way to Vertue is ſo eaſy Sir.

sp.speaker: Ant
sp.p: I alwayes thought it, there's none but a company of ill-natur'd moroſe people that would have it hard can think it otherwiſe.

sp.speaker: Ped.
sp.p: Can any one believe that ſuch a glorious thing as woman is, was made to be conceal'd?

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: No, 'tmuſt be curſed Hereſie, I had rather they ſhould put out the Sun by half.

sp.speaker: Pache.
sp.p: That's becauſe you love their company in the dark. Was not that good, Tutor?

sp.speaker: Tut.
sp.p: Excellent!

sp.speaker: Ped.
sp.p: Hey day! who have we here? I have heard of Guardian Angels, but never thought that Divels were ſo employed before.

sp.speaker: Tutor.
sp.p: You know the faſhion Sir of your own Country. This is the ſweet-meat keeper, the preſerver of Maiden heads that ſhall for a Ducat corrupt youth, and teach them more bawdy in a week than half a dozen years practice; yet is truſted with as much beauty as is able to make the great Turks Empire run mad, merely for being old and ill natur'd. In ſhort Sir here our Reformation muſt begin.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: Come at her then.

sp.speaker: Nurſ.
sp.p: What do you mean Gentlemen? I'me onely a poor old Servant to the houſe.

sp.speaker: Pedro.
sp.p: Thy being old is enough to make us hate thee.

sp.speaker: Pacheco.
sp.p: Come where are my Siſters? give me the keys.

sp.speaker: Nurſ.
sp.p: No ſuch matter, my Maſter charged me but juſt now to the contrary, and I will be true.

sp.speaker: Pacheco.
sp.p: Give me them you Witch or—

sp.speaker: Nurſ.
sp.p: I'le cry out, will you force me?

sp.speaker: Pedro.
sp.p: Have you got them?

sp.speaker: Pacheco.
sp.p: Yes, Yes.

sp.speaker: Pedro.
sp.p: But how ſhall we ſtop her mouth? an old womans tongue is harder to lay than ten Divels.

sp.speaker: Anto.
sp.p: Let me alone with her, I go always prepared to ſtop theſe noiſes.

div.stage: Ant. Gags and binds her and throws her out.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: There lie thee there, and dare but ſo much as think miſchief, and do you hear I'le pull out the two ſtumps that are left.

sp.speaker: Pacheco.
sp.p: Here Gallants take theſe keys. Now you may enter and catch who catch can a la mode d' Angleterre, I diſturb nobody not I.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: A kind Brother this! Aſide it ſhall go hard but I will have a Siſter for you Sir.

sp.speaker: Lea.
sp.p: My jealouſie makes it but too true I am in love, and that with ſuch reſpect that 'tis impoſſible to benefit by this freedom.

sp.speaker: Tut.
sp.p: Courage Sir, I perceive you are one of the cold contemplative lovers that follow a Miſtriſs at a diſtance, and think your ſelf happy if you purchaſe one gracious nod, with ten thouſand cringes. In for ſhame.

sp.speaker: Pacheco.
sp.p: If you'l carry me to one of your Ladies, I'le ſoon teach you better courtſhip. Or if you'l ſtay here. You ſhall ſee me practiſe.

sp.speaker: Lean.
sp.p: I ſhall be glad to learn Sir.

sp.speaker: Pacheco.
sp.p: Come Tutor ſhow me the way of addreſs to a Lady.

sp.speaker: Tutor.
sp.p: Did you never ſee the Gallants in the Antechamber, how they prepare themſelves before entrance?

sp.speaker: Pacheco.
sp.p: Yes I warrant, what was I in England ſo long for elſe? but will that do?

sp.speaker: Tutor.
sp.p: The very ſame.

div.stage: Sets his wig and ſhirt and tricks himſelf.

sp.speaker: Pacheco.
sp.p: Then thus.
How do you like this Sir?

sp.speaker: Lea.
sp.p: Oh Sir much beyond any thing I ever ſaw. I muſt have patience with this fool for his Siſters ſake.

sp.speaker: Tutor▪
sp.p: Then Sir we don't go your formal old way of making legs, as if we had ſome Deity to worſhip. But knowing they are fleſh and blood as well as we approach briskly.

sp.speaker: Pacheco.
sp.p: Begin with an oath or two. I think it is not much matter whether it be to the purpoſe or not Tutor.

sp.speaker: Tutor.
sp.p: Not at all Sir, they'l excuſe all that follows for the ſake of that.

sp.speaker: Lean.
sp.p: Theſe are great ſecrets, you improve me Gentlemen.

sp.speaker: Pac.
sp.p: Nay Sir, if we carry on our Reformation, the whole ſtate will ſtand engaged to us, but great deſigns ſeldom proſper at the firſt.

sp.speaker: Lean.
sp.p: The more's our ignorance, but pray Sir in. If there be ſuch a toy as a Maſque or Fan to play with, or you can find any thing new about her to commend 'tis modiſh, and the moſt gentile ſubject for diſcourſe.

sp.speaker: Tut.
sp.p: If you name two or three Ladies of quality familiarly, it ſounds well and brings you in eſteem. But moſt of all if you can learn who ſhe hates (for women have always little quarrels amongſt themſelves) and can pick up a ſtory to their diſadvantage, you render your ſelf beyond exception acceptable.

sp.speaker: Pacheco.
sp.p: I do it alwayes, but nothing pleaſes them ſo much as a little ſprinkling of bawdy Tutor. Only the Divels in't, the rogues perpetually out-do me at it.

sp.speaker: Tutor.
sp.p: No wonder Sir, they practiſe daily, and no three women that are acquaintance but make a Bawdy language for their own uſe.

sp.speaker: Pach.
sp.p: I wiſh you had a Siſter Sir, or ſo, that you might ſee me practiſe or'e theſe lectures,

sp.speaker: Lean.
sp.p: 'Tis my misfortune Sir.

sp.speaker: Pache.
sp.p: But ſuppoſe for once that you were my Miſtriſs.

sp.speaker: Lea.
sp.p: Content.

sp.speaker: Pacheco.
sp.p: Thus I come up.
sp.stage: Sings a piece of a Tune.
sp.p: And how? damn me Madam all a mort?

sp.speaker: Tutor.
sp.p: Incomparably well!

sp.speaker: Lean.
sp.p: Muſt I ſwear too?

sp.speaker: Pach.
sp.p: No Sir by no means, if the women once get that (as there is a faction amongſt them that endeavour it) they rob us of half our diſcourſe. But ſay vvhat you vvill I have nevvs from the laſt Ball, or of ſome nevv Beauty kept by ſuch a one. Or a nevv Play to find fault vvith or commend according as I hear vvho made it.

sp.speaker: Tutor.
sp.p: And vvhen you once get them into the diſcourſe of Plays they'l run on themſelves. Praiſe ſuch an Actor for this part, a ſecond for another, a third for a comely man, a fourth for dancing vvell.

sp.speaker: Pache.
sp.p: Nay Sir, if you meet vvith a vvoman that does not find you diſcourſe on this ſubject, conclude her ſome Jilt that never had the good luck to be pickt up there, or ſome poor vvhore that can't purchaſe a ſeat.

sp.speaker: Lean.
sp.p: But vvhat do you do all the time?

sp.speaker: Pache.
sp.p:
Comb my Wig by her glaſs and tvventy other
gentile tricks. But you muſt have time to learn, I my ſelf am beholden to travel, and this good man my Tutor here.

sp.speaker: Lea.
sp.p: I deſpair of e're attaining ſuch perfections.

sp.speaker: Pache.
sp.p: Induſtry may do much, Sir.

sp.speaker: Tutor.
sp.p: So, here they come; does not this look better than making legs to a belcony and blowing kiſſes up and down.

sp.speaker: Pache.
sp.p: This is right. Bleſt Reformation!

sp.speaker: Lean.
sp.p: I find this Engliſh cuſtom will not down with me, I'me too much an Italian not to be jealous of the thing I love.

sp.speaker: Mari.
sp.p: You may think us rude for to be thus familiar; but a Fathers ſtrictneſs, and my Brothers good leſſons have inſtructed us.

sp.speaker: Pedro.
sp.p: It's nothing Madam but what becomes all People that are Vertuous; 'tis only ſuch as drive a trade, and gain by ſeeming nice that ſhould be otherwiſe.

sp.speaker: Iſm.
sp.p: Phy Siſter, you ſin againſt our Covenant to go about t' excuſe your ſelf; for my part I think we need none, I'me ſure our ſouls are free as any mans: And yet forſooth our bodies muſt be confin'd, and that by old men and women too, people by their very natures made unfit for liberty.

sp.speaker: Anto.
sp.p: Brave Virago! You ſhall be our Captain Madam in this holy war.

sp.speaker: Pach.
sp.p: She's my own Siſter Sir, you ſee that.
This is a modeſt Gentleman of the Reformation, pray bid him welcome. I and my Tutor have been reading to him and we have hopes of his improvement.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: Your friend muſt challenge welcome here, Brother.

sp.speaker: Iſm.
sp.p: The being a Reformer gives it him in's own right.

sp.speaker: Lean.
sp.p: You heap your honors too faſt on me Ladies, and the obligation is too far above my merit.

sp.speaker: Pach.
sp.p: There's ſtuff indeed. Can't you ſerve her as I told you I would one of your Siſters? But the firſt fault ſhall be pardon'd.

sp.speaker: Lean.
sp.p: Still worſe it gnaws here.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: Fie Brother, the Gentleman ſpeaks well.

sp.speaker: Pach.
sp.p: Yes if he would hold up his head a little, and not begin with ſuch a long word as obligation.

sp.speaker: Lean.
sp.p: I have loſt all patience.

sp.speaker: Pach.
sp.p: Mark Sir, you ſhould cringe thus, ſpeak two or three half ſentences, as, I vow Madam, take me but, and all that. And then come up boldly.

sp.speaker: Lean.
sp.p: 'Tis well you are her Brother. I find
sp.l: I muſt contrive my ends ſome other way,
And when ſhe's once a wife ſhe ſhall obey.

sp.speaker: Tut.
sp.p: You may end your Lecture, the Gentleman's gone Sir.

sp.speaker: Pach.
sp.p: Gone! then let him live in ignorance.

sp.speaker: Mari.
sp.p: If you're always thus exact brother, we ſhall ne're increaſe our Company.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: You muſt pardon him, he was always humorſome.

sp.speaker: Pach.
sp.p: 'Tis ſtrange, when People have ſuch opportunities and wont improve themſelves.
Art thou come dear Rogue? let me kiſs the. Here Siſters, ſhare him, this is my ſecond that I told you of. If we meet with any oppoſition in our great affair.

sp.speaker: Piſ.
sp.p: But that we meet on the deſign of freedom Ladies, I might eaſily have been thought rude to have intruded thus.

sp.speaker: Iſ.
sp.p: Nothing but your free humor can make you welcome here.

sp.speaker: Piſ.
sp.p: 'T would be happineſs to purchaſe it at any rate, but this doubles the favour Madam.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: Fie Sir, this ſounds too like a Compliment. We ſhould be loth to loſe the good opinion we have of you.

sp.speaker: Pach.
sp.p: Have done for ſhame or I ſhall read you one of your friend Leandros Lectures.

sp.speaker: Piſ.
sp.p: Pray what have you done to make him leave your Company?

sp.speaker: Ped.
sp.p: Truſt me nothing but mirth, but Lovers are humorſome.

sp.speaker: Piſ.
sp.p: Sir, no more.

sp.speaker: Pach.
sp.p: Come Gallants now we're met, what think you of a Dance?

sp.speaker: Anto.
sp.p: We want Muſick and Ladies.

sp.speaker: Pach.
sp.p: Not ſo faſt good Sir, here's two to four of you, in England 'tis common to go halfes, and the women never complain neither. No, no. The Muſick, is the thing. Oh Tutor for the four and twenty Engliſh Violins now. You'd think your ſelves in Heaven, Gentlemen, at a new Play. There we ſtand up with our Miſtreſſes in our hands, keep time and court them to the humor of the aire, have one particular ſort of ſtrain to gripe at, another for a languiſhing look. We Italians find fault with your Tramontanes, but we are dull we are dull to them.

sp.speaker: Piſa.
sp.p: Pray let's defer that for our next meeting; if theſe Ladies will but honor me to be my gueſts, I'le take care theſe wants ſhall be ſupplied.

sp.speaker: Pach.
sp.p: I'le engage for them.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: Now we have begun this way of freedom we ſhould be uncivil to deny you Sir.

sp.speaker: Iſm.
sp.p: But how ſhall we get looſe?

sp.speaker: Piſa.
sp.p: That ſhall be provided for before we part. It is but juſt the firſt time be ſpent in the publick ſervice.

sp.speaker: Tut.
sp.p: Some Chairs there.

sp.speaker: Anto.
sp.p: Well propoſed, and that the rules of Reformation be decreed by joint conſent.

sp.speaker: Ped.
sp.p: At leaſt that every one ſhould undertake beſides the Generall work, ſome one particular for to advance the Reformation.

sp.speaker: Piſ.
sp.p: Let's to the conſultation then.

sp.speaker: Ped.
sp.p: Firſt I propoſe Pacheco be voted perpetual Chair-man to the Society; as one of whoſe faithfulneſs and zeale we've had ſufficient proof.
All. Agreed.

sp.speaker: Pach.
sp.p: W' accept the honor Gentlemen, and hope we may deſerve it by our future diligence.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: Come Ladies will it pleaſe you ſit.

sp.speaker: Iſm.
sp.p: Do you uſe t' admit of women to your privy counſel?

sp.speaker: Ped.
sp.p: Yes Madam they ſtill have had the caſting vote in every Reformation.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: Nay then wee'l never loſe our Priviledge.

sp.speaker: Pach.
sp.p: Firſt I declare my Tutor ſecretary.

sp.speaker: Piſ.
sp.p: You've made a happy choice.

sp.speaker: Pach.
sp.p: Next, as a thing that's very much conducing to the Reformation, I undertake to regulate and be the pattern of all faſhions in the town. To further which my Secretary ſhall diſpatch and keep a correſpondence with our beloved pattern England.

sp.speaker: Piſ.
sp.p: Why not with France? they borrow all from thence.

sp.speaker: Tut.
sp.p: True Sir, and I have known ſome ſcores of Gallants that ſail thither twice or thrice a year on that deſign. And are expected by the reſt with as much earneſtneſs as the Eaſt-India fleet by thoſe that make the greateſt venture.

sp.speaker: Pach.
sp.p: Yes Tutor, but they make ſome new additions of their own; as your fring'd glove, curle of the wig, or cut of the belt, which ſtrikes me ſtrangely. Beſides, they much improve the gate and ceremony. And out-do the French in their own way cringe and wadle.

sp.speaker: Ped.
sp.p: Theſe are Arguments beyond objection. I undertake t'invent a Language for the company, I mean ſome twenty words or more of conſtant uſe. Or ſenſe or not, all's one ſo long as faſhionable.

sp.speaker: Pach.
sp.p: Good, and the true Genteel Engliſh way of wit. You ſhall have a Gallant pay his devoirs, teſtifie his amours, and make his aſſignations ſome twenty times a day.

sp.speaker: Ped.
sp.p: To this I'le add as many ſtories too. To which we muſt refer all our diſcourſe. This ſerves inſtead of whiſpering.

sp.speaker: Tut.
sp.p: Oh much better; but then the Ladies muſt engage to ſeem to underſtand and laugh at all you ſay.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: That's eaſy, for we always do pretend to know more than we do.

sp.speaker: Iſm.
sp.p: 'Tis but as all that would be thought great wits do, Siſter.

sp.speaker: Piſ.
sp.p: I have a project now on foot which will advance the Reformation, but beg I may once more try the experiment before I do reveal't.

sp.speaker: Pach.
sp.p: It's granted. What ſay you Antonio?

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: Why I will undertake for to reform all the old men in Venice to the Engliſh way. Expect within a week to ſee them in their Wigs and with their chins new ſhav'd, like boys of fifteen. Nay more, I do intend for to begin with old Camillo too himſelf.

sp.speaker: Piſ.
sp.p: 'Tis a bold project, ſucceed or not.

sp.speaker: Tut.
sp.p: For my part I'le ſtick to my old way and write you Plays and Songs. I know they never fail. I'le undertake the laſt nevv Play or tvvo I vvrit made the young Ladies more free, and brought more kind couples together, than all the old vvomen or Pages in the Country.

sp.speaker: Pach.
sp.p: Probatum eſt. I've reap'd the benefit of that my ſelf. What ſay the Ladies novv?

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: We can only promiſe for to follovv your inſtructions, Gentlemen.

sp.speaker: Iſm.
sp.p: And that vve do in every thing: vvith a little more experience we may venture to undertake ſome project of our ſelves.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: Bravely reſolved Ladies. No cauſe can fail that's backt by two ſuch Champions.

sp.speaker: Tut
sp.p: Will you give me leave to give you ſome advice.

sp.speaker: Pach.
sp.p: Leave? you're Tutor to the Society.

sp.speaker: Tut.
sp.p: Then firſt —

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: Heark what noiſe is that, for Heaven ſake look out. Oh we're undone Siſter.

sp.speaker: Iſm.
sp.p: 'Twill be in good company then.

sp.speaker: Tut.
sp.p: 'Tis Antonio's Boy.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: Is he coming?

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.p: Yes Sir.

sp.speaker: Pach.
sp.p: Away with theſe things there quickly.

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.p: He is not very near yet.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: Go out and give us more notice.

sp.speaker: Piſ.
sp.p: Ladies, if you follow my advice you may have freedom without fear.

sp.speaker: Iſm.
sp.p: We'l follow any thing to purchaſe that.

sp.speaker: Piſ.
sp.p:
Here onely take this Powder, and when your Father
calls for wine mingle it with this, within an hour it will make him ſleep, and you free.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: But is there no danger Sir?

sp.speaker: Piſ.
sp.p: A child may take it Madam.

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.p: He's juſt here.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: Then we have no time for complement.

sp.speaker: Piſ.
sp.p: You remember your promiſe Ladies. Come Pacheco you ſhall go along with me, it ſhall be hard but I will have a Miſtriſs for you. This does but ſet thy teeth on edge.

sp.speaker: Pach.
sp.p: This way, this way, by the back door.

div.stage: Mariana and Iſmena pull out their works.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: Pray Siſter let's be very dutiful for fear he ſhould miſtruſt.

sp.speaker: Iſm.
sp.p: I warrant you; do you think I am to learn to counterfeit at fifteen?

sp.speaker: Cam.
sp.p: Now I'me pleaſed, be ſtill thus dutiful, and you ſhall find me an Indulgent Father. I am contriving ſomething unto your advantage Mariana, you ſhall hear it ſhortly.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: I ſhall wait your commands Sir.

sp.speaker: Cam.
sp.p: That was well ſaid, and for you too Iſmena.

sp.speaker: Iſm.
sp.p: If it pleaſes you Sir I muſt needs be ſatisfied, I was always taught to be dutiful.

sp.speaker: Cam.
sp.p: Thou haſt thy Mothers ſoul. I am o'rejoy'd to find thee thus. Where's the Nurſe?

sp.speaker: Iſm.
sp.p: I forgot to tell you Sir, as ſoon as you went out, ſhe was taken with a moſt violent raving fit. And talkt and rayled ſo loud ſhe quite frighted us.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: Then on the ſudden was ſtruck dumb. And has not ſpoke one word ſince.

sp.speaker: Cam.
sp.p: Poor woman. I'le go ſee her.

sp.speaker: Iſm.
sp.p: No, pray Sir ſhe's now faſt and you'l diſturb her.

sp.speaker: Cam.
sp.p: Well thought on. 'tis only reſt that muſt compoſe her. But hark what noiſe is that! Again!

sp.speaker: Iſm.
sp.p: 'Tis the Nurſe, for Heaven ſake Siſter run and ungag her we're undone elſe, and leave me to my Father.

sp.speaker: Cam.
sp.p: What's the houſe hanted at this time of day?

sp.speaker: Iſm.
sp.p: 'Tis only the poor Nurſe Sir that wakes in her diſtracted fit.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: Good dear, dear Nurſe.

sp.speaker: Nurſe.
sp.p: Not I, it ſhall out.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: I'le give you my beſt Peticoat, good Nurſe.

sp.speaker: Nurſ.
sp.p: Not all the world ſhall hire me. Oh Sir!

sp.speaker: Iſm.
sp.p: Pray Siſter help me to hold her. Her fit increaſes, Lord how her eyes rowl! Aſide Sweet Nurſe I'le give thee any thing.

sp.speaker: Nur.
sp.p: Oh Maſter! Such a noiſe, ſuch ſinging, nay pray Heaven it were no worſe, for they were roaring Boys.

sp.speaker: Cam.
sp.p: She raves indeed, what doſt mean Nurſe?

sp.speaker: Nurſe.
sp.p: I mean here Sir, with your daughter ſome five or ſix of them.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: Poor old creature, how ſtrong her fancy is? let's bind her Sir, they ſay that that will hinder it.

sp.speaker: Cam.
sp.p: Here's no body but I and you and my two daughters.

sp.speaker: Nurſ.
sp.p: But there was Sir. Heaven grant you have no grandchildren in ſtore, for I begin to doubt them.

sp.speaker: Iſm.
sp.p: Juſt thus ſhe talkt before ſhe ſlept, a little Opium would do well to ſettle her. (good Nurſe.

sp.speaker: Nurſe.
sp.p: You think to carry it off, but now my Gag's out it ſhall be known. And how you contrived.

sp.speaker: Cam.
sp.p: I found them here at work alone.

sp.speaker: Nurſe.
sp.p: I'me apt to think they're work was done before you came Sir.

sp.speaker: Cam.
sp.p: Pray Iſmena, what does ſhe mean by this?

sp.speaker: Iſm.
sp.p: Heaven knows, ſome ſad diſtraction Sir, I doubt ſhe has been wicked in her youth.

sp.speaker: Nurſ.
sp.p: Come, Come I doubt you are. I ſee old Age and Service cannot be believed.

sp.speaker: Iſm.
sp.p: Mark Siſter, now ſhe's in her crying fit too. I'le call for help and put her to bed.

sp.speaker: Ser.
sp.p: Here's a Gentleman without that calls himſelf Leandro, Sir, has buſineſs with you.

sp.speaker: Cam.
sp.p: I come, carry out the Nurſe and let the Maids look after her.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: I think they had beſt bind her. Pray Heaven ſhe do no miſchief.

sp.speaker: Iſm.
sp.p: Her teeth are all out, ſhe can't bite.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: Now what do you think on't Nurſe?

sp.speaker: Nur.
sp.p: I think you're all poſſeſt, for to abuſe me thus. All that vexes me, I ne're deſerv'd it at my Maſters hands. But I will be reveng'd.

sp.speaker: Iſm.
sp.p: This is beyond expectation. Pray Heaven our next frolick ſucceed as well.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: I'me ſtrangely afraid of this Leandro.

sp.speaker: Iſm.
sp.p: That's the Melancholy man that was with us, is it not?

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: The ſame; if he betray us we're undone yet.

sp.speaker: Iſm.
sp.p: Ne're fear wench, this powder will be one ſhift more.
sp.l: And whether Fortune ſmiles or knits her brow,
We can't be worſe than ſlaves, and ſo we're now.

sp.speaker: Lean.
sp.p: I thought my ſelf engaged beſides the particular love I bear your daughter, by my tie to honor to declare this truth.

sp.speaker: Cam.
sp.p: 'Tis very ſtrange.

sp.speaker: Lean.
sp.p: The Nurſe can juſtifie it.

sp.speaker: Cam.
sp.p: Why, ſhe's diſtracted Sir.

sp.speaker: Lean.
sp.p: She might well ſeem ſo, abuſed as ſhe has been.

sp.speaker: Cam.
sp.p: Come in with me and wee'l examine further, and if it does prove true, I ſtand obliged.

sp.speaker: Lean.
sp.p: If not, then take your own revenge.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.p:
'Twas well we had this notice, we had been ſurprized elſe. What unlucky buſineſs brings him back? Now muſt I be
kiſt and hugg'd by one I hate. Phaugh. He ſaid Lyſander told it him himſelf, did he not?

sp.speaker: Lel.
sp.p: Yes, Madam.

sp.speaker: Jul.
