sp.p: Very well, the more he doats on's Mis, the more time ſhall I have with my Gallant, and if he does chance to find me out I have ſomething to cry quit with. In the mean time I'le ſeem as fond as ever, leſt he ſhould ſuſpect me.

sp.speaker: Lel.
sp.p: Heark Madam, I think I hear him coming.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.p: Yes, 'tis he.
Next I will have you work the diſmal ſtory of poor Ariadnes love, and how the cruel Theſeus left her, 'twas unkindly done Lelia: But men are not ſo fond as we.

sp.speaker: Lyſ.
sp.p: Pox of your counterfeit pipe, he has been here but fled.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.p: Ar't' come deareſt? now thou'rt kind indeed, a ſuddain joy o'rewhelming me. I was juſt talking of the cruelties of men, and pittying our poor ſex. But I had never yet a cauſe to doubt of thee. Ten thouſand welcomes. I have had ſuch fears.

sp.speaker: Lyſ.
sp.p: Leſt I ſhould come home too ſoon Aſide. Thou art ſo fond, I muſt believe thee, I am o'rejoy'd to find thee in this health. Truſt me I've ſcarcely ſlept ſince laſt we parted.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.p: No, you had one that kept you waking Aſide Poor Dear I pitty thee; you wanted me to ſing and kiſs thee to thy reſt.

sp.speaker: Lyſ.
sp.p: Truth is, no Opium cauſes ſleep ſo much as ſuch a bedfellovv. —I hate Aſide.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.p: Nay I my ſelf have had the ſtrangeſt dreams too.

sp.speaker: Lyſ.
sp.p: I hope they vvere all pleaſant ones.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.p: They vvere all of you, you night and day diſpoſe my thoughts. One time methoughts you loved another vvoman more than me, that troubled me a little, as it vvould any vvife that loves ſo vvell as I do. But I believe there are but fevv.

sp.speaker: Lyſ.
sp.p:
Heaven forbid there ſhould. Aſide That vvas thy
too much fondneſs, thou can'ſt not have thoſe thoughts avvake.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.p: No deareſt joy, 'tvvas only in a dream.

sp.speaker: Lyſ.
sp.p: That's nothing, for I had ſuch a one of you, but when I wak'd I chid my ſelf.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.p: Nay, then we're even, and muſt pardon one another.

sp.speaker: Lel.
sp.p: There's reaſon for't, for you are both ſinners.

sp.speaker: Lyſ.
sp.p: I am ſo far from a miſtruſt, that I dare ſwear thou art as innocent, as I my ſelf.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.p: I dare pawn my innocence for thee too.

sp.speaker: Lel.
sp.p: And if you ne're redeem't 'tis no great loſs.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.p: But why ſhould we talk thus? it looks too like miſtruſt. Believe me t'was with me an Age till your return.

sp.speaker: Lyſ.
sp.p: The very laſt hour before mine, ſeemed months to me too. I would fain have taken you napping.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.p: Poor rogue, you're thin ſince laſt I ſaw you, you ſhall not go agen.

sp.speaker: Lelia.
sp.p: A Miſtriſs and a Wife's enough to mak any body look ſo.

sp.speaker: Lyſ.
sp.p: Nay deareſt but I muſt, and leave thee for a week or two, an hour is the longeſt of my ſtay.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.p: And of my life. You will kill me.

sp.speaker: Lyſ.
sp.p: It ſhall be with kindneſs then.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.p: A week! I know thou'rt not in earneſt but vvilt deceive me thus agen, come prithee do, theſe ſurprizes make thy coming ten times pleaſanter.

sp.speaker: Lel.
sp.p: That vvas vvell nickt, to make ſure vvork.

sp.speaker: Lyſ.
sp.p: 'Tis too certain, Juliana, that's the leaſt; nay, never cry for't. But let's enjoy that little time vve have, come prithee leave.
sp.l: They ſay that married peoples Loves decay,
But mine ſtill grovvs

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.l: And mine, —another vvay.

div.head: SCENE I.

sp.speaker: Piſ.
sp.p: COme hang't, vvhy all this mincing? can you imagine I'me ſo dull as not to ſee through it? Ten to one I knovv the cauſe of your Mumps; as much, I find the riſe of your ſullenneſs. In ſhort Pedro you have a months mind to meaſure lengths vvith Madam Mariana, and you Antonio have as much to a day to try hovv things vvill fit vvith brisk Iſmena. Come, confeſs, confeſs; I ſee plainly by your ſolemn pace and grave contriving looks, you have been running over all the ſtories in Romances to accompliſh your deſigns.

sp.speaker: Ped.
sp.p: I muſt declare that I have no averſion to the freedom of her humour.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: And I have ſeen ſome faces and conditions which I have liked much worſe. But —

sp.speaker: Piſ.
sp.p: Pox on you both! don't you think this ſounds very prettily to one that has been an Adventurer, in this trade of love? You muſt give me leave to know that your no averſion is the height of deſire, and your liking much worſe is the ſame with nothing half ſo well. But this ſilly love ſtill thinks, becauſe he's blind himſelf, no body elſe muſt ſee.

sp.speaker: Ped.
sp.p: Nay, Pray Piſauro, for charity invent ſome other name, though it ſhould prove the ſelf ſame thing, for this is ſcandalous.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: No, No, 'tis ſo, I plainly ſee all men have a certain time allowed to play the fool, and love in, and this is mine.

sp.speaker: Piſ.
sp.p: This is honeſt and a friendly part. But why the Divel don't you tell them ſo? you ſee we're more put to't to lay the jealouſie of old Camillo, than we ſhould be to raiſe a Ghoſt, to gain an houres leiſure.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: I thought I ventured fair conſidering t'was the firſt time.

sp.speaker: Piſ
sp.p: That's very fine, the firſt time? is not the Gallant worthy more applauſe that hits the mark the firſt ſhoot, than he that draws a dozen times and ne're comes nigh the ſpot? I'me ſure the Ladies will commend him for his aime.

sp.speaker: Ped.
sp.p: But you know the Cuſtom does require Ceremony.

sp.speaker: Piſ.
sp.p: As for cuſtomes, our Reformation is deſign'd for to deſtroy them all. And this firſt in ſhort Gentlemen, there are but two wayes you can deſign to be poſſeſſours of your hopes: either to perſwade them to their faſhionable way of love, or be content your ſelves to marry them.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: But neither of theſe, I doubt, will do, Piſauro; 'tis certain they are too wiſe and vertuous for the firſt; too brisk and jolly for the ſecond.

sp.speaker: Piſ.
sp.p: Truth is, their briskneſs makes me fear they are honeſt.

sp.speaker: Ped.
sp.p: Could I find them otherwiſe, I ſhould ſoon make an end of all my love.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: Faith, thought I formerly have had no great opinion of the other, yet I reſolve to try it now, and carry on the Reformation too. Venice ſhall learn from me the freedom due to Wives. What ſayeſt thou, Pedro?

sp.speaker: Ped.
sp.p: Nay, I am too much thy friend to leave thee in the greateſt hazard of thy life.

sp.speaker: Piſ.
sp.p: Well agreed. I ſhall give you opportunity anon, if my deſign ſucceeds with old Camillo: though I begin to doubt becauſe the Tutor comes not. By this Pacheco and his Miſtriſs have chang'd a broad-ſide or two; I left them nigh engaging.

sp.speaker: Ped.
sp.p: There is no danger in the combat I preſume.

sp.speaker: Piſ.
sp.p: Faith, not on her ſide, ſhe has little to loſe beſides the Veſſel, let him board her when he will.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: Have you got the Tutors conſent yet?

sp.speaker: Piſ.
sp.p: That I intend to buy with gold and good words, and the money will be well put out to uſe too; the fool muſt needs be rich, and the wench I know has wit enough to wheadle him.

sp.speaker: Ped.
sp.p: But do you think he'le bite home enough to marry?

sp.speaker: Piſ.
sp.p:
Yes, I know ſhe'l ſtand upon her honour, the unknown
value of a womans credit, and twenty ſuch common places they all inherit from their Mothers, and if he once grow hot he will do any thing.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: Have you heard any news of Leandro?

sp.speaker: Piſ.
sp.p: Yes, but am loth to tell a ſtory ſo imperfect; the Tutor will tell us all.

sp.speaker: Ped.
sp.p: Does that Fellow continue his old humour ſtill?

sp.speaker: Piſ.
sp.p: Without the leaſt change, if not improved.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: Prithee put him into 't a little.

sp.speaker: Piſ.
sp.p: You'l repent you, for 'tis intolerable.

sp.speaker: Ped.
sp.p: No, No, for once we'l venture it.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: 'Tis much that this fellow that has wit, and is company in every thing beſides, ſhould thus beſot himſelf.

sp.speaker: Ped.
sp.p: Let's work a cure and beat him out of this humour.

sp.speaker: Piſ.
sp.p: If beating would have done he had been well long ere this.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: Methinks change of air ſhould work.

sp.speaker: Piſ.
sp.p: No, nothing, he picks out half a dozen young fools where e're he comes, ſticks to them till he has talk'd o're all he has to ſay, and then changes. But st.

Here he comes, let's diſpatch our buſineſs firſt: Welcome Sir, what news? you look as if you'd had a Play hiſt, or met with ſome preſumptuous fool that would pretend to underſtand the rules of Poetry in your company.

sp.speaker: Tut.
sp.p: No none of theſe, but ſomething that concerns you nearer at the preſent: in ſhort, Leandro has betray'd all, renounced his covenant, and become Reprobate.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: Faith, I expected no better, I knew he muſt neceſſarily turn Heretick by this way of living: alas, he drunk nothing but Penitential water and dangerous Coffee, half a dozen ſuch Sneaks would ruin the Republick.

sp.speaker: Ped.
sp.p: Prithee, what new light or Revelation rules him now?

sp.speaker: Tut.
sp.p:
The old flame of Love, and he goes the old Italian way to work too: makes his addreſſes to the Father without conſulting the woman: Has told of your being there, the Rules of your Reformation; and by this art ſo wheadled
him that he reſolves to marry one of his daughters to him immediately; to which end he's juſt now gone to fetch a Prieſt. Yonder has been ſuch a Lecture, what between the old man and the Nurſe, that the Poor Ladies have been worried.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: Which of the Siſters is't?

sp.speaker: Piſ.
sp.p: Iſmena, that's it which vexes me, h'as pickt the flower out of all our conqueſt.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: But he ſhall hang before he e're ſhall wear her.

sp.speaker: Ped.
sp.p: No, it muſt not be; if we let the firſt rebellion proſper, we betray the weakneſs of our Government.

sp.speaker: Piſ.
sp.p: I knew him falſe before, and therefore promiſed to aſſiſt you in your loves, from hence I do renounce all friendſhip with him as a Traytor.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: Thou art truly Loyal. Pray let me beg the freedom to contrive his puniſhment; if I make him not as wretched and ridiculous as his worſt of enemies can wiſh, truſt me with no more affairs of State.

sp.speaker: Ped.
sp.p: But how ſhall we eſcape this danger?

sp.speaker: Piſ.
sp.p: Has be taken the powder yet?

sp.speaker: Tut.
sp.p: Yes, that's all our hopes. He railed himſelf ſo dry that he was forced to call for wine If that works before Leandro comes, we ſhould be freed for the preſent, the Nurſe too has a doſe to ſpoil her talking.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: That's well, could we but meet him.

sp.speaker: Tut.
sp.p: He muſt come this way, for he went towards the Arſenal.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: Then we are ſafe, let me alone to manage him.

sp.speaker: Piſ.
sp.p: In the mean time let us divert our ſelves.

sp.speaker: Tut.
sp.p: I thought to have met Pacheco here, 'tis certain he muſt not come nigh home till old Camillo is appeaſed; nor I neither.

sp.speaker: Piſ.
sp.p: He's in a ſafer place practiſing all his Lectures over to his Miſtriſs. I have a project now on foot which if you'l promiſe to advance you ſhall want no gold; but of that anon.

sp.speaker: Tut.
sp.p: I ſhall endeavour to ſerve you Sir.

sp.speaker: Piſ.
sp.p: Come Sir you are a judge, what opinion have you of the laſt new Play?

sp.speaker: Tut.
sp.p: Faith— well for an eſſay. I gueſs the Gentlemans but a beginner. I my ſelf—

sp.speaker: Piſ.
sp.p: Now he's in.

sp.speaker: Tut.
sp.p: Writ with the ſame much ſucceſs at firſt, 'twas induſtry and much converſe that made me ripe; I tell you Gentlemen, when I firſt attempted this way I underſtood no more of Poetry than one of you.

sp.speaker: Ped.
sp.p: This is ſtrange impudence.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: 'Tis nothing yet.

sp.speaker: Tut.
sp.p: There are many pretenders but you ſee how few ſucceed; and bating two or three of this nation as Taſſo, Arioſto and Guarini, that write indifferently well, the reſt muſt not be named for Poeſy: we have ſome three or four, as Fletcher, Iohnſon, Shakeſpear, Davenant, that have ſcribled themſelves into the bulk of follies and are admired to, but ne're knew the laws of heroick or dramatick poeſy, nor faith to write true Engliſh neither.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: 'Tis very much, I hope Sir your heroick play goes on.

sp.speaker: Tut.
sp.p: As faſt as a piece of that exactneſs can. I'le only leave a pattern to the world for the ſucceeding ages and have done.

sp.speaker: Ped.
sp.p: Oh Sir you'l wrong the world.

sp.speaker: Tut.
sp.p: No faith Sir I grow weary of applauſe.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: Will you give me leave to ask the way for others to attain to your perfection?

sp.speaker: Tut.
sp.p: I will not ſay but that it may be done, but truſt me you'l find it hard Gentlemen, and ſince you are my friends I'le tell you.

sp.speaker: Ped.
sp.p: You will oblige us Sir.

sp.speaker: Tut.
sp.p: Firſt I ſpeak of Tragedy, which let the world ſay what it will and doat on little things, I ſcrible now and then, as good faith they doe Gentlemen ſtrangely; you ſhall have them— but I don't love to praiſe my ſelf. Tragedy I ſay's my Maſterpiece.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: Every tthing you do ſeems ſo.

sp.speaker: Tut.
sp.p:
Nay, nay, pray forbear Gentlemen—To go on: I take a ſubject, as ſuppoſe the Siege of Candy, or the conqueſt
of Flanders, and by the way Sir let it alwayes be ſome war-like action; you can't imagine what a grace a Drum and Trumpet give a Play. Then Sir I take you ſome three or four or half a dozen Kings, but moſt commonly two or three ſerve my turn, not a farthing matter whether they lived within a hundred years of one another, not a farthing Gentlemen, I have tryed it, and let the Play be what it will, the Characters are ſtill the ſame.

sp.speaker: Piſ.
sp.p: Truſt me Sir, this is a ſecret of your art.

sp.speaker: Tut.
sp.p: As Sir you muſt alwayes have two Ladies in Love with one man, or two men in love with one woman; if you make them the Father and the Son, or two Brothers, or two Friends, 'twill do the better. There you know is opportunity for love and honour and Fighting, and all that.

sp.speaker: Ped.
sp.p: Very well Sir.

sp.speaker: Tut.
sp.p: Then Sir you muſt have a Hero that ſhall fight with all the world; yes i'gad, and beat them too, and half the gods into the bargain if occaſion ſerves.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: This method muſt needs take.

sp.speaker: Tut.
sp.p: And does Sir. But give me leave and mark it for infallible, in all you write reflect upon religion and the Clergy; you can't imagine how it tickles, you ſhall have the Gallants get thoſe verſes all by heart, and fill their letters with them to their Country friends; believe me this one piece of art has ſet off many an indifferent Play, and but you are my friends—

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: You honour us.

sp.speaker: Tut.
sp.p: Laſt of all, be ſure to raiſe a dancing ſinging ghoſt or two, court the Players for half a dozen new ſcenes and fine cloaths (for take me if there ben't much in that too) put your ſtory into rime, and kill enough at the end of the Play, and Probatum eſt your buſineſs is done for Tragedy.

sp.speaker: Piſ.
sp.p: A'n 't you weary?

sp.speaker: Ped.
sp.p: No prithee let him run on.

sp.speaker: Tut.
sp.p: Then as for Comedy, which I vvas ſaying my Genius does not lead me to, but that the vvorld may knovv I can at idle houres vvhen I pleaſe out-vvrite them, I do venture at.

sp.speaker: Piſ.
sp.p: And with ſucceſs Sir too, believe it.

sp.speaker: Tut.
sp.p: And faith Gentlemen I'le tell you, there's your French Nation, Pox on 't a kind of Jack-pudding wit, yet hang me if their Plays be well pick'd, as a ſcene here and a ſcene there, it will do it, it will i' faith, I have try'd it.

sp.speaker: Ped.
sp.p: Well Sir proceed.

sp.speaker: Tut.
sp.p: But your true Engliſh and my way, is to vvrite your Plays with double ſence and brisk meaning Songs. Take me, you ſhall have the Ladies laugh at a little bawdy jeſt as if they would bepiſs themſelves, and the young Mounſieurs clap as if they meant to wear their hands out in the ſervice; and if you conſider, this is eaſy and a large ſubject, eſpecially to one that will be at the charge to keep a wench that underſtands her trade, you can't imagine what hints and pretty things ſhe will pick up. Now Sir, if you can but maintain two or three of thoſe Characters, no matter what your plot is, your love and honour will do here agen, and 'tis but ſaving alive and marrying thoſe that you would kill in Tragedy, and you have done.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: We give you thanks for theſe inſtructions, and ſhall endeavour to improve Sir.

sp.speaker: Tut.
sp.p: Nay, I have not done yet, but if you promiſe ſecrecy will let you know my great Arcanum.

sp.speaker: All.
sp.p: We do.

sp.speaker: Tut.
sp.p: 'Tis this, when I have writ a Play, I pick ſome Lady out of general acquaintance, or favourite at the Court, that would be thought a wit, and ſend it in pretence for to ſubmit it to her judgment. This ſhe takes for ſuch a favour— and raiſes her eſteem ſo much—ſhe talks of nothing elſe but Mr. ſuch a ones new Play, and picks out the beſt on 't to repeat, ſo half the town by this means is engag'd to clap before they come.

sp.speaker: Ped.
sp.p: Excellent!

sp.speaker: Tut.
sp.p: Beſides this, I take ſome half a dozen youngſters of the town, People that pride themſelves in one of my nods or a ſhaking by the hand at the Coffee-houſe, and let them have a copy of a Song or two, or promiſe of the Prologue, which does ſo much oblige, that I have all the faction of the town that makes a noiſe on my ſide.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: Truſt me Sir theſe are very great rules.

sp.speaker: Tut.
sp.p: And ſuch as never fail, but I am reſolv'd to leave, and having made a pattern for the world ſo long deceiv'd in their opinion of wit and Language.

sp.speaker: Ped.
sp.p: For heaven ſake pitty us now Piſauro, and perſwade him to keep this for his Aſide Preface to the next new Play.

sp.speaker: Piſ.
sp.p: Not I, ſince you have wound him up, may you be deaf with noiſe.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: Here comes one that will releaſe us then.

sp.speaker: Piſ.
sp.p: We muſt keep him in talk a while.
Leandro here! that's a miracle, where haſt thou been for heavens ſake? thou might'ſt have found the North paſſage to the Indies ſince I ſaw thee.

sp.speaker: Lean.
sp.p: Troth Gentlemen I have found out as difficult a one to as pleaſant a place, and am juſt going to reap the benefit of my adventure.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: We may all ſhare I hope.

sp.speaker: Lea.
sp.p: No, I'me for c'd to monopoliſe for all the ſweets and treaſures of the place, if once they're blow'd upon or toucht by more than one, loſe all their value and delight.

sp.speaker: Ped.
sp.p: Are you the firſt diſcoverer that you challenge ſuch propriety?

sp.speaker: Lea.
sp.p: I've reaſon to think ſo, for th' acceſſes were all guarded by a watchful dragon.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: In plain language Sir.

sp.speaker: Lea.
sp.p: I'le tell you then becauſe I am in haſt; ſince I left you I have been with old Camillo, drawn up writings, agreed every thing between us, and only want a Prieſt (which is juſt going thither) to make Iſmena mine; was not my paſſage ſhorter than ordinary, Gentlemen, and the Iſland worth diſcovery? Pray Gentlemen how does the Reformation go forward?

sp.speaker: Piſ.
sp.p: But haſt thou no remorſe, no pricking all this time?

sp.speaker: Lean.
sp.p: For what prithee?

sp.speaker: Piſ.
sp.p:
Is thy zeal for the ſolemn covenant ſo ſoon forgot? how dares thou ſin after this rate and rob a woman of her
liberty which thou haſt ſworn to defend at leaſt, if not procure?

sp.speaker: Ped.
sp.p: You are too haſty Piſauro, without queſtion he will give her all ſhe wiſhes and the Reformation askes.

sp.speaker: Lean.
sp.p: No, you're deceiv'd Sir, though I was Engliſh when a batchelour, I'le be a true Italian and my ſelf, when married. I value her credit and my quiet too much to do otherwiſe.

sp.speaker: Piſ.
sp.p: Then may all Cupids curſes light upon thee.

sp.speaker: Lean.
sp.p: I dare venture ten times more than that blind boy is able to inflict for ſuch a prize, farewel Gentlemen.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: Nay, ſtay and take all with you, may'ſt thou be impotent in th' height of all thy wiſhes.

sp.speaker: Ped.
sp.p: Be jealous, yet never have a cauſe.

sp.speaker: Piſ.
sp.p: Run mad with dotage and ſhe ſcorn thee.

sp.speaker: Lean.
sp.p: Leave, leave I ſhall grow fat with curſing.

sp.speaker: Piſ.
sp.p: Thou ſhalt have enough to burſt thee then.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: May'ſt thou have Sons, yet never dare to own them, and they beg their bread.

sp.speaker: Ped.
sp.p: May thy daughters be ſo rank to doat on Monkeys.

sp.speaker: Piſ.
sp.p: May'ſt thou live to ſee all this and hang thy ſelf.

sp.speaker: Lean.
sp.p: I'm pleas'd to ſee you envy me; and you have cauſe, for I ſhall have delights lawful and wholeſome too, when I ſhall meet you trayling of your legs after you or walking upon crutches with but one noſe among you. Adieu laughs or will you go with me and believe your eyes?

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: We will, lead us; and if fair means don't, force ſhall.

sp.speaker: Piſ.
sp.p: Come Tutor, as we go I'le tell you my deſign which you muſt further.

sp.speaker: Cam.
sp.p: Come 'tis in vain to whine, I will not ſleep till I have don't.

sp.speaker: Iſm.
sp.p: You may be deceiv'd for all this yet.
Courage Siſter he begins to yawn already.

sp.speaker: Cam.
sp.p:
I'le ſee whether a Nunnery and a husband can reclaim
you. Nor ſhall it go much better with your gewgaw Brother. Are you ſo rampant, you muſt make a decoy of my own houſe to catch your wild fowl in?

sp.speaker: Ma.
sp.p: Give me ſome little time for to prepare my ſelf.

sp.speaker: Ca
sp.p: Oh you have done that to the purpoſe, ſinner enough to ſpend the reſt of your life in penitence.

sp.speaker: Iſm.
sp.p: There's another, it will do.
Pray Sir let me live there and bear her company.

sp.speaker: Cam.
sp.p: No, though you're both naught, I'de willingly keep one of you to breed on, and it ſhall be you, a Nunnery will give you too much liberty.

sp.speaker: Iſ.
sp.p: If I muſt marry give me leave to choſe.

sp.speaker: Ca.
sp.p: Your choice is likely to be good by the company you keep; but I've provided for you, you ſhall be kept ſo cloſe you ſcarcely ſhall have light enough yawns to read your prayers by.

sp.speaker: Iſ.
sp.p: That's too cruel, I would pray for you.

sp.speaker: Ca.
sp.p: It muſt be backward then; thy youth is all the reaſon I can give to think thou'rt not a witch; O' my conſcience thou can'ſt fly, but I'le have your wings clipt, and you put into a Cage for better ſecurity.

sp.speaker: Nur.
sp.p: They have been wild indeed yawns took I what care I could.

sp.speaker: Cam.
sp.p: Why do'ſt thou yawn ſo, thou infects me too.

sp.speaker: Nur.
sp.p: You ſee Ladies though I have no teeth I can find my tongue.

sp.speaker: Iſ.
sp.p: I propheſie that you will loſe it yet e're long, for vvronging of the innocent.

sp.speaker: Cam.
sp.p: Welcome Son, I was vvaiting for you.

sp.speaker: Lean.
sp.p: I've brought my friends along, the Gallants of the Reformation, to ſee me happy and to take their leave.

sp.speaker: Cam.
sp.p: I ſhall take care to reform my daughters from keeping them company, yawns you have ſpoiled a Son of mine too among you

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: Who do you ſpeak Sir to?

sp.speaker: Cam.
sp.p: To you all.

sp.speaker: Nur.
sp.p: To you Sir, ſince you are ſo brisk yawns this is the very Royſter that gag'd and bound me Sir.

sp.speaker: Piſ.
sp.p: Let's look, thou gap'ſt as if thou had'ſt a gag there yet.

sp.speaker: Lean.
sp.p: How is't Sir, you look not well; your eyes are heavy too.

sp.speaker: Cam.
sp.p: Only a little weary and faint yawns with chiding of theſe wicked girles.

sp.speaker: Lean.
sp.p: Wil't pleaſe you ſit? A Chair there.

sp.speaker: Nur.
sp.p: How is't Sir?

sp.speaker: Cam.
sp.p: Pray take away this gaping woman yawns and let us fin—fin—fin—iſh—

sp.speaker: Nurſ.
sp.p: Wil't pleaſe you to have a little yawns cordial water, or yawns ſome aqua mi—mirabilis, or—or.

div.stage: Falls a ſleep leaning on Cam.

sp.speaker: Lean.
sp.p: Believe me Madam, it proceeded all from Love.

sp.speaker: Iſm.
sp.p: I muſt obey Sir.

sp.speaker: Piſ.
sp.p: He's faſt, he's faſt Madam.

sp.speaker: Iſm.
sp.p: Then I am free.

sp.speaker: Ma.
sp.p: And I ſhall ſcarcely ſay my Prayers in a Nunnery to day; how lovingly they ſleep!

sp.speaker: Lean.
sp.p: How's this! you have not murdered him.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: Nothing but a gentle ſleep Sir, which does our buſineſs as well.

sp.speaker: Ped.
sp.p: Was you ſo ignorant to think wee'd let thee carry it thus?

sp.speaker: Piſ.
sp.p: What my wiſe Coffee-drinker over-reacht?

sp.speaker: Lean.
sp.p: This is beyond all ſufferance, what ſay you Madam? will you refuſe me too?

sp.speaker: Iſm.
sp.p: Oh Sir, I would not marry without my Fathers leave for all the world.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: Send you joy Sir, we believe our own eyes.

sp.speaker: Lean.
sp.p: I'le never ſtay for to be baited thus.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p:
Nay, prethee ſtay a while, and let me tell you a ſecret, you'l want news elſe. We gave this ſleeping portion to Camillo and the Nurſe, to gain an opportunity of going
out to laugh and dance: Remember Sir: and kept you in diſcourſe till this time, when we were ſure it would work, for to prevent your marriage: Do you mark Sir? ſome few houres hence he wakes, and then you may come again and tell your ſtory.

sp.speaker: Lea.
sp.p: Yes, and be revenged.

sp.speaker: Piſ.
sp.p: If you dare make a ſecond triall, this is but purgatory, you know the next puniſhment.

sp.speaker: Lean.
sp.p: Sunk in the height of all my hopes.

sp.speaker: Piſ.
sp.p: Well Gallants, I'le before and leave you to wait upon the Ladies.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: But whither prithee?

sp.speaker: Piſ.
sp.p: To Lyſandro's here hard by.

sp.speaker: Ped.
sp.p: He's not at home.

sp.speaker: Piſ.
sp.p: But his wife is, that's as good.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: Nay 'tis much better; does your furnace ſtand there?

sp.speaker: Piſ.
sp.p: Ladies I ſhall wait you.

sp.speaker: Ma.
sp.p: Whoſe within there?
Pray Tutor call ſome body to carry theſe in and ſet them warm.

div.stage: Enter Servants, carry off Cam. Nurſe.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: Now have I a ſtrange deſign comes into my head.

sp.speaker: Ped.
sp.p: What is't?

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: You know Gallants I promiſed to reform the old men; what if we ſhould ſhave Camillo, head and chin, and let him wake in a great white wig?

sp.speaker: Iſm.
sp.p: For heavens ſake, that would make him irreconcileable.

sp.speaker: Ped.
sp.p: No, No, that's driving on too faſt, we're pretty well advanced.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: I only do propoſe. Come Ladies ſhall we go?

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: Yes Sir, I wiſh our mirth ends well.

sp.speaker: Iſ.
sp.p: Fie Siſter to think of that before it does begin.

sp.speaker: Pa.
sp.p: I vow to gad Madam nothing but an affair of this moment and that—

sp.speaker: Lel.
sp.p: Oh Sir you have honoured me.

sp.speaker: Pa.
sp.p: Oh Gad Madam the honour—and but that I know your goodneſs Dear Madam—let me periſh but—one minute returns me as much your humble Servant, as—your Servant Madam, your ſervant.

div.head: Scena Secunda.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.p: I'me glad to find your new gallant tickles ſo.

sp.speaker: Lel.
sp.p: He would make a Nun laugh that's juſt profeſt, and that's the ſorrowful'ſt laughs time I can think of; all I wonder at is, that I live.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.p: What's the matter? did he ſtand upon his head or conjure, that he's ſuch a miracle?

sp.speaker: Lel.
sp.p: I know not what you mean by conjuring, but all the juglers at a Carnival have not ſo many tricks.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.p: I muſt get ſome muſick for thee, O' my conſcience thou art ſtung wench, prithee leave and ſpeak.

sp.speaker: Lel.
sp.p: Why Madam all the Painters ſince the art was found out, ne're drew half the poſtures he was in, in leſs than half an hour, he goes as puppets do by wiers. Pray Madam have a little patience and I'le ſhew you. After a ſhrug and a ſalute, which he tells me is the new mode, he gives his little whalebone a twirle or two.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.p: Well then I make my curtſy.

sp.speaker: Lel.
sp.p: Right Madam, then the Divel refuſe him. But mine's the pleaſant'ſt ſeat in Venice, and that gives him opportunity to take as ſtrut or two to view the room; but all this time the wig and ſhirt is order'd, and as ſoon as e're the looking glaſs was ſpied, out comes the comb, and I had twenty tunes begun and never ended, or ended and ne're begun.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.p: But what muſt I do all this while?

sp.speaker: Lel.
sp.p: Admire Madam, then the poſture's alter'd, and off goes the glove vvhich ſhovvs the diamond ring, and out comes the gold Watch, vvhich muſt be placed vvith art, for fear the chain hang not out enough to be ſeen.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.p: Thou'rt a Divel to abuſe him thus.

sp.speaker: Lel.
sp.p: Next he approaches and knovvs I am a vvit by the choſing of my ribbons, and rails at the poor Country Madam, for making him ſvveat in Summer vvith her hot colours. Next ſubject of diſcourſe vvas the alteration of the mode in Laces; commends my vvork, and calls all the ſtitches by their proper names, and in the midſt of this begins a nevv tune, ſvvears 'tis good, and from thence takes occaſion to run over all the Plays and his acquaintance vvith the Poets.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.p: Could'ſt thou deſire better company?

sp.speaker: Lel.
sp.p: Nay he has not done yet Madam; then he talks o're all the women of the town, and how Tom ſuch a one, had turn'd off Betty, and Dick ſuch another kept Mall, and call'd them all by their names as freely as if he had been Pimp to all the company.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.p: And ten to one their names is all he knows them by, but you muſt know 'tis modiſh and a great attainment.

sp.speaker: Lel.
sp.p: At laſt when he came into the diſcourſe of travel, I concluded we ſhould ne're have done, but all o'th' ſuddain he makes me three or four cringes of ſeveral faſhions, begs leave for to diſpatch ſome great affair (which I ſuppoſe was to look upon ſome new wig he had beſpoke) and hee'd be here immediatly.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.p: And vvhat doſt thou think of him after all this?

sp.speaker: Lel.
sp.p: You muſt needs gueſs Madam, as of a moſt egregious Fop. I'm beholden to Piſauro for his good vviſhes.
And here he comes in time for to receive my thanks.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.p: I am aſhamed to hear thee talk thus, vvhat bleſſing can'ſt thou imagine greater than a husband that's a fool and rich?

sp.speaker: Lel
sp.p: Heaven forbid Madam.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.p:
Thou'rt an Idiot: Is't not better to have him buſy
himſelf with points and ribbons, toys and laces, than to be alwayes grave and melancholy, which in a while will make him jealous too and mark your very looks.

sp.speaker: Piſ.
sp.p: 'Tis odds but that you're lock't up, and ſee the Sun but once a twelvemonth, and have no other company but ſome old woman that does the office of a deaths head and puts you in mind of dying.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.p: You ſee what arts I'me forc'd to uſe to cheat Lyſander with, ſuch a man as this will manage all your purpoſe himſelf.

sp.speaker: Lel.
sp.p: I will be rul'd by you Madam.

sp.speaker: Piſ.
sp.p: 'Twas well ſaid, how did he behave himſelf?

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.p: I have had that at full, no more now I beſeech you.

sp.speaker: Piſ.
sp.p: How did you carry it?

sp.speaker: Lel.
sp.p: I took your directions, and had as many modiſh poſtures as I then could think on, ſometimes thus, then thus.

sp.speaker: Piſ.
sp.p: That muſt needs take him, did he ſpeak any thing of Love?
sp.stage: She acts ſeveral ridiculous conceited poſtures.

sp.speaker: Lel.
sp.p: I can't tell how to anſwer you, or what his way of courtſhip is when he's in earneſt, but he commended me as if I was to ſell, grip'd my hand and kiſt it, talk't of the power of love and women, and all the time ſcrew'd up and down as if he had been netled.

sp.speaker: Piſ.
sp.p: Theſe are good ſigns, I ſhall know all as ſoon as e're I ſee him:Pacheco ſings within. heark! I believe he's coming, yes 'tis he I hear him ſing, pray withdraw; the Ladies will be here immediately.

sp.speaker: Piſ.
sp.p: Save you Sir, you're got off alive I ſee.

sp.speaker: Pa.
sp.p: Yes faith, and that's all; hang me Piſauro if ſhe is not the firſt woman that has moved me on this ſide England.

sp.speaker: Piſ.
sp.p: I thought 'twas ſhe muſt nick your humor.

sp.speaker: Pa.
sp.p: Take me if ſhe has not vvit too and demean, underſtands addreſs and all that.

sp.speaker: Piſ.
sp.p: This character from you vvill raiſe her in my eſteem.

sp.speaker: Pa.
sp.p: You muſt give me leave to underſtand a little.

sp.speaker: Piſ.
sp.p: You are the only judge, Sir.

sp.speaker: Pa.
sp.p: Believe me ſhe has the true Court air, takes every thing that's nevv and modiſh. I'le ſvvear to you, I have ſometimes caſt an afternoon avvay, run through all my common places of diſcourſe, and at the laſt been thought ridiculous.

sp.speaker: Piſ.
sp.p: You muſt meet vvith women that have been barbarous then.

sp.speaker: Pa.
sp.p: No Sir, 'twas want of breeding and converſe, not one in ten that has the leaſt of it. Alas Sir, there's a particular mine, languiſhing look, and je ne ſcay quoy, as we ſay, and all this ſhe has in perfection. Take me, if I don't think there is a perfect ſympathy between us. But this thing of friends.

sp.speaker: Piſ.
sp.p: You are Melancholy of the ſuddain.

sp.speaker: Pa.
sp.p: No Sir, I am only contriving ſomething to advance our Reformation, and to make us perfect.

sp.speaker: Piſ.
sp.p: It will do.

sp.speaker: Pa.
sp.p: And it ſhall be hard but I'le out-do you all.

div.stage: Enter Anto. Pedro, Tutor, Juliana, Mariana, Iſmena, Lelia.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.p: All the entertainment I can promiſe is your freedom, Gallants, and that you're in a houſe where you have all things at command.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: There's nothing can be added Madam.

sp.speaker: Piſ.
sp.p: Now you honour me, I have invited you to an Engliſh treat, Ladies, room and muſick, you bring the mirth and company with you.
Some Chairs there.

sp.speaker: Pa.
sp.p: I have been ſo rude as to encreaſe your company without your knowledge, Sir, to day I ſwore a ſtranger and invited him, he promiſed me to bring his Miſtriſs too.

sp.speaker: Piſ.
sp.p: The leaſt acquaintance Sir with you muſt challenge welcome.

sp.speaker: Pa.
sp.p: I know you'l like his humor, 'tis free beyond any thing I ever met on this ſide the Alpes. I in a moment found that we were made for one another's company.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.p: That free humor which you ſpeak of brings a welcome with it.

sp.speaker: Ped.
sp.p: This looks well, we were made for this.

sp.speaker: Iſm.
sp.p: Methinks we begin to live now, we did but dream away our time before, Siſter.

sp.speaker: Ma.
sp.p: It was not half ſo pleaſant; but now you ſpeak of dreaming, Heaven keep my Father faſt.

sp.speaker: Iſm.
sp.p: I reſolve to think of nothing here but mirth.

sp.speaker: Piſ.
sp.p: Bravely ſaid Madam. Come let's be frolick then.

sp.speaker: Pa.
sp.p: My Tutor has provided us a dance was made to ſet off his new laſt Play in England.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: Pray let us have it then, 'tmuſt be as proper here as there.

sp.speaker: Tut.
sp.p: I'le ſtep out and get it ready.

sp.speaker: Piſ.
sp.p: Will it pleaſe you ſit Ladies? Some wine there.

div.stage: They go to ſet two women together.

sp.speaker: Pac.
sp.p: Two women together! let us never begin our Reformation with ſuch a ſin, come I'le teach you better, and as Maſter will begin an Engliſh health. Here, here ſtand a Lady and a Gallant. Now Madam a health to my Mis and your Gallant.

sp.speaker: Lel.
sp.p: Here Sir, here's a health to my Gallant and your Mis.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: Right, Right, fill it about.

sp.speaker: Pac.
sp.p: So now all hands.

lg.l: Fill round the healths good natur'd and free,
No cuſtom our joyes ſhall defer.
Each Lady has her Gallant, each man has his Mis,
Let us kiſs, let us kiſs, A la mode d'Angle terre.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.p: If this be an Engliſh cuſtom, 'tis a mighty kiſſing country, this is too much.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: Right! I knew ſhe that liked it beſt would be the firſt that ſhould complain.

div.stage: They all ſit a man and a woman.

sp.speaker: Tut.
sp.p: Strike up there.

sp.speaker: Piſ.
sp.p: Come Sir have you never another health?

sp.speaker: Pa.
sp.p: A thouſand.

div.stage: As he's going to drink, Enter Lyſander, Emilia.

sp.speaker: Lyſ.
sp.p: Shall I keep my reſolution?

sp.speaker: Em.
sp.p: Yes prithee do for my ſake.

sp.speaker: Pa.
sp.p: Dear heart! I wiſh autority can bid you welcome now.

sp.speaker: Lyſ.
sp.p: I thank you Sir, but I can make my ſelf ſo.

sp.speaker: Piſ.
sp.p: 'Slife thou haſt undone us man, why this is husband to the Lady in whoſe houſe we are.

sp.speaker: Pa.
sp.p: What then he's ſworn, and 'tis as common for a wife to make a ball without her husbands knowledge, as for a Nun to ſay her Prayers; is't not Tutor?

sp.speaker: Tut.
sp.p: Yes Sir, 'tis nothing, or with their konwledge either: Lyſander all this time compliments the Ladies. More, the good man rather than his wife ſhall loſe a kiſs, takes her by the hand and tells the next man that comes, my wife Sir, and then ſhe's ſlaver'd round the company.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: This muſt be Lyſander, what can this come to?

sp.speaker: Ped.
sp.p: At the worſt we muſt reſolve to carry off the Ladies ſafe.

sp.speaker: Lyſ.
sp.p: 'Twas kindly done to comfort up the widdow Gentlemen, come ne're diſturb your ſelves, I'm a ſworn Brother.

sp.speaker: Piſ.
sp.p: Reſolve to carry't off briskly, there's no other way left.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.p: Art' come deareſt? ten thouſand vvelcomes, you ee vvhat ſhift I'm forc'd to make to comfort me in ſolitude; but all's too little for to make amends for one Lyſander.

sp.speaker: Lyſ.
sp.p: Dear rogue thou can'ſt not think hovv much I vvanted thee too, you ſee vvhat paultry ſhift I vvas forced to make.

sp.speaker: Pa.
sp.p: She's vvondrous fair, Madam—

sp.speaker: Lyſ.
sp.p: Hold, hold, Sir, though I allovv all freedom with my vvife, you knovv the Engliſh faſhion is to keep my Miſtris to my ſelf.

sp.speaker: Pa.
sp.p: I beg your pardon Sir, 'tvvas vvell remembred.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.p: I ſee you're angry, but I vvas forced to ſeek to eaſe my grief by any vvay vvhen you vvas abſent.

sp.speaker: Lyſ.
sp.p:
Not I, ne're trouble your ſelf to make this excuſe, I
love this mirth; but prithee chuck tell me, vvhich of theſe is thy Gallant? or do they take't by turns, come prithee do, good faith I count my ſelf beholden to him, he eaſes me.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.p: I ſee no faithfulneſs can e're oblige you.

sp.speaker: Lyſ.
sp.p: Novv thou art too modeſt, for ſhame Piſauro ovvn her, I knovv I pay for all that finery.

sp.speaker: Lyſ.
sp.p: Nay vve'l be man and vvife ſtill in any place but bed, and that vvant you have provided for your ſelf, ne're trouble your ſelf. If you do more than e're I could Piſauro, and ſhe prove fruitful, I promiſe here to be a Godfather. If I have the ſame ſucceſs here, I expect the like kindneſs from you Juliana.

sp.speaker: Tut.
sp.p: This is true love.

sp.speaker: Pa.
sp.p: Novv our Reformation goes forvvard in good earneſt.

sp.speaker: Ma.
sp.p: It amazes me; vvould I vvere free from hence once.

sp.speaker: Lyſ.
sp.p: Come, come, Gentlemen, be frolick, you ſeem troubled; Is not this better than ſlitting of noſes or a ſtab Gentlemen? we can call chuck and joy and twenty ſuch pretty names ſtill, as well as the very beſt of them.
Nay faith Ladies one dance more for my ſake, I ſhall grieve that I diſturbed you elſe.
Muſick there

sp.speaker: Lyſ.
sp.p: Now be but pleas'd to take a ſmall collation in the next room, and I ſhall believe you think your ſelves welcome.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: We'l wait you Sir.

sp.speaker: Ma.
sp.p: Yet I'me impatient till I'me gone.

sp.speaker: Ped.
sp.p: There's no danger Madam.

sp.speaker: Iſm.
sp.p: I fear none Sir.

sp.speaker: Pac.
sp.p: Let me periſh elſe.

sp.speaker: Lel.
sp.p: You make me bluſh Sir.

sp.speaker: Pa.
sp.p: Let me die if any thing's more ſerious.

sp.speaker: Lyſ.
sp.p: Come how is't joy?

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.p: Thank thee Deareſt.

sp.speaker: Lyſ.
sp.l: The world may laugh, and names of ſcorn invent,
But to be Cuckolds nothing if content.

sp.speaker: Lyſ.
sp.p: TIs ſtrange that we can faſten no ſuch thing as honor upon the Sex, whereas a man's lies every where. Twinge him by the noſe, his honour's there, and preſently muſt be redeem'd.
Kick him, and 'tis remov'd to's backſide, and muſt be engaged.
But this of woman-kind is really nothing. For if one unmarried chance to kick up her heeles, the reproach returns upon the family.
Or if a wife prove gameſome more than ordinary, ſhee's thought a wit, and cunning; and 'tis the husband's branded with the name of ſcorn.

Now ſhould I go kill Piſauro to redeem my honour: and if I do, die honourably by an Executioner, or fly my Country: Or if I fall my ſelf, they'l cry there died a ſilly cuckold, worth the while. I thank my ſtars I'me leſs nice in theſe points, and have found out a ſafer way.
Welcome deareſt, I was ſending for thee.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.p: I fear'd you might be angry.

sp.speaker: Lyſ.
sp.p: What for ſuch petty faults?

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.p: Nay now you ſpeak as if you did not think me honeſt.

sp.speaker: Lyſ.
sp.p: Not honeſt? Why you know I have no reaſon to the contrary: Prithee no more on't, I wou'd make a bargain with thee.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.p: With me Sir? What do you mean?

sp.speaker: Lyſ.
sp.p: In ſhort, what is't you're willing to take a year for alimony?

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.p: This is harder than the firſt.

sp.speaker: Lyſ.
sp.p:
'Tis that, that muſt be underſtood, for I reſolve to carry on my part in the Reformation by this means. Conſult
your ſelf and friends, for I would have you live in credit ſtill.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.p: Pray Sir be plain.

sp.speaker: Lyſ.
sp.p: Why thus.

Write me down ſo much for cloaths, ſo much for diet, and lodgings: ſomething too for pleaſure I'le allow; 'tis the ſaving Engliſh way, and 'tis but reaſonable when a wife proves falſe, ſhe ſhould be ſtinted, and the overplus ſhould keep a Miſs. Come, come, I'me out of my frollick humor now, and am ſerious.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.p: Now you are cruel, will you quite ruine me?

sp.speaker: Lyſ.
sp.p: No ſuch matter, I'le be as civil too as any man, only retrench ſome ſmall ſums you us'd to ſpend in charitable uſes, as fourty pound to ſuch a Nunnery, aliàs for a new ſuit; twenty unto ſuch a Monaſtery, aliàs a new Wigg: why ſhould you be laviſh in your good deeds? There's ſcarce a Covent in the town but's bound to pray for you.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.p: Pray pardon me, you us'd to ſay you loved me.

sp.speaker: Lyſ.
sp.p: I pardon you with all my heart; but I'le take care that you ſhall ſin no more with my purſe, nor let Piſauro brave it with my wealth, as I know he does; come, it is in vain for to deny.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.p: Nay if you grow angry once, Emilia does ſo to; why ſhould not I have the ſame liberty?

sp.speaker: Lyſ.
sp.p: There are ſome thirty and odd reaſons to the contrary, beſides the common practice; but that which muſt ſatisfie you is, I will not have it ſo, and 'tis in my power to hinder it, remember what I ſay.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.p: Oh Piſauro, we're undone.

sp.speaker: Piſ.
sp.p: Come, no ſuch matter, I have overheard it all, if Pacheco marry Lelia, as 'tis almoſt out of doubt, this ſore will ſoon be heal'd; beſides my fortune's not ſo very low, but I can live, and your allowance will be fair, I dare promiſe.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.p: But will you ſtill love me?

sp.speaker: Piſ.
sp.p: I'le double it if poſſible.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.p: All that troubles me is, I ſhall want my wealth to ſerve you with.

sp.speaker: Piſ.
sp.p: Prithee no more, we loſe time, Lelia be careful not to ſeem too coy, but if he comes to ſteal you let him carry off the prize: Friends, or the grave will ſoon reconcile Camillo: I muſt thither and ſee how affairs go, come courage Madam we can never want.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.p: I fear nothing but loſing my Gallant.

sp.speaker: Lel.
sp.p: I'me reſolv'd to make ſure of mine.

div.head: Scena Secunda.

sp.speaker: Pa.
sp.p: Am I exact in every thing? the colours ſuited? and my cloaths cut with the modiſh air?

sp.speaker: Tut.
sp.p: To a thought: You ſee what 'tis to imploy a Taylor knowing in the faſhion. There's nothing like your French cut Sir, you ſhall have a country Gentleman come to town, and throw away a years revenue on a ſuit on purpoſe to be laught at, hang me if a Livery been't more creditable.

sp.speaker: Pac.
sp.p: Then there's much in the wearing of them too, why here now, what would this belt be valued at, without I wore it? Now it imploys the hands, and gives a grace to all the gate.

sp.speaker: Tut.
sp.p: I joy to ſee you thus improved, you may read to me ſhortly. Oh dear Pupil.

sp.speaker: Pac.
sp.p: Then there's the cock of the hat, tying of the ſhirt, faſhions of crevats, the wearing of a Wig that's friz'd or curl'd, things that alter daily, and that theſe poor fools can ne're pretend to.

sp.speaker: Tut.
sp.p: You amaze me Sir, I ſhall grow proud of my ſucceſs.

sp.speaker: Pa.
sp.p: Take me if I had not rather paſs a judgment of a man, from a ſhake a la mode, wearing of a Miſtreſſes faver, or the tying of a knot (there's a perfect Genius ſhown in that) than from a months converſe.

sp.speaker: Tut.
sp.p: You have reaſon Sir; theſe are the things men travel for, truſt me you may be a pattern to the very Author of the faſhion. Nay if you're once reſolved I know you muſt needs carry her, but—

sp.speaker: Pa.
sp.p: No more objections good Tutor.

sp.speaker: Tut.
sp.p: Not I Sir, I ſee ſhe's fair, believe her vertuous and a fortune, but yet—

sp.speaker: Pa.
sp.p: More but's yet? now I begin to think thou envieſt me, 'tis certain I will do ſomething ſhall make me chief; truth is, Lyſander bid fair for the command, but at the laſt I've found it, and defie him, and all the reſt, to think of Conqueſt.

sp.speaker: Tut.
sp.p: May I know it?

sp.speaker: Pa.
sp.p: Yes on condition you'l not ſpeak a word to hinder my deſign.

sp.speaker: Tut.
sp.p: Since you are ſo reſolute I engage.

sp.speaker: Pa.
sp.p: Then thus. I will to Lelia thus dreſt as I am, which certainly muſt do't, and without the leaſt enquiry after fortune, or conſent of friends marry her for love; the height of Gallantry, and top of Reformation, hah?

sp.speaker: Tut.
sp.p: I may Sir.

sp.speaker: Pach.
sp.p: Not a word.

sp.speaker: Tut.
sp.p: I may go with you Sir.

sp.speaker: Pac.
sp.p: No, I'le have the honor of the action my ſelf, when I return expect me conqueror.

sp.speaker: Tut.
sp.p: No doubt of that, you'l find but little oppoſition.

sp.speaker: Pac.
sp.p: I can but think when 'tis done what pleaſures I ſhall have, and bleſt occaſions of new words; As, my Joy, my chuck, my dear, my ſweet honey-comb, and ſhe anſwers in as good a ſtile; for I reſolve to teach her all the Engliſh words. Adieu.

sp.speaker: Tut.
sp.p: Send you a fair wind, I've gold depends upon your good ſucceſs.

sp.speaker: Piſ.
sp.p: Well met Tutor, where's Pacheco? we muſt not let him cool.

sp.speaker: Tut.
sp.p: There's no fear: he juſt now left me, with a Reſolution to conclude before he will return.

sp.speaker: Piſ.
sp.p: Then we're happy: his ſwearing of Lyſander was unlucky.

sp.speaker: Tut.
sp.p: It muſt be pardon'd, 'twas perfect zeal and ignorance.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: Save ye Gentlemen: what news from Camillo, Tutor?

sp.speaker: Tut.
sp.p: They were both faſt within this half hour.

sp.speaker: Piſ.
sp.p: 'Tis much about the time they are to wake.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: Shall we beg a favor from you then Sir?

sp.speaker: Tut.
sp.p: You may command it Madam.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: 'Tis that you'd watch my Father, and give us notice when he ſtirs.

sp.speaker: Tut.
sp.p: I fly to ſerve you.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: 'Twas bravely carryed by Lyſander.

sp.speaker: Ped.
sp.p: That, that pleas'd me was, he nickt the Reformation too.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: To a thought: There if the women be diſpleaſed, 'tis but finding a pretence of quarrel, ſue their husbands, and the law gives them the thirds of the Eſtate to keep Gallants with.

sp.speaker: Piſ.
sp.p: I can hardly recover my ſelf though I know I'me out of danger: I would have parted with the little of my Eſtate to any man breathing for a new Song.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: Faith at the beſt 'twas but a leaſe, and that fairly forfeited to the Lord too.

sp.speaker: Ped.
sp.p: What will you take for't now it's renew'd Piſauro?

sp.speaker: Piſ.
sp.p: Not renewed upon ſo good termes as you imagine; but I'le not part with it, whilſt the ground bears any crop.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: 'Tis ſtrange the very being women ſhould oblige us to diſſemble thus.

sp.speaker: Iſm.
sp.p: You ſee 'tis true, for my part I do confeſs I love and would give all the world to marry my Antonio.

sp.speaker: Mar
sp.p: I Pedro. Know 'tis the only remedy for our misfortunes, yet muſt not let them know it.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: Fie Ladies not out of your fright yet!

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p:
Yes Sir we were talking of a greater danger; for
though I'me naturally devout, I don't love to ſay my prayers on force.

sp.speaker: Iſm.
sp.p: And though I have no hatred againſt mankind, yet to have one thruſt upon me thus, goes a little againſt the hair.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: We have propoſed a way, that will prevent both dangers, would you follow it.

sp.speaker: Iſm.
sp.p: I run the ſame hazard of a husband.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: And I one worſe than that, of being Nun.

sp.speaker: Ped.
sp.p: Why Madam, can you think it better to trifle time away in telling beads, and change your youth and briskneſs for Melancholy looks and wrinckles?

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: And you reſolve to ſigh away your life ſome three ſtories high, make complaints, and talk to the men it'h' Arras? That muſt be your fortune if you wed Leandro.

sp.speaker: Iſm.
sp.p: Suppoſe all this true, how can you have the confidence to ask us for to marry you? Is it neceſſary we muſt break our necks to avoid drowning? Or to ſhun my fathers making us ſlaves go ſhackle up our ſelves?

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: As for liberty, you ſhall make your own propoſitions.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: Which you will keep religiouſly until you've married us, and then break at pleaſure.

sp.speaker: Ped.
sp.p: How can you imagine to avoid this danger?

sp.speaker: Iſm.
sp.p: Pugh, that we'l think on when it comes, at preſent we are free.

sp.speaker: Piſ.
sp.p: But to be ſerious Ladies be your own Judges, is there not ſomething in the Society of men you much deſire?

sp.speaker: Iſm.
sp.p: Confeſt, but ne're will purchaſe it at ſuch a rate as marriage.

sp.speaker: Piſ.
sp.p: Why then you muſt reſolve to be kind without it. 'Tis a hard caſe if you neither lead nor drive.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: That we muſt be ſtretcht upon a rack, for no fault too, without the leaſt hope of eaſe.

sp.speaker: Iſm.
sp.p: What can you deſire more than this freedom?

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: Very much: That is the very thing deſtroyes our hopes, were you but ſimpring, mimping, bridling Ladies, you were ſure prize; thoſe ſort of cattel are ſo little us'd to ſpeak, they think it modeſty not to deny you.

sp.speaker: Piſ.
sp.p: Or what do you think of a down demure look?

sp.speaker: Ped.
sp.p: That never fails neither, I always challenge them, and what they mean for baſhfulneſs, conclude a certain ſign of guilt.

sp.speaker: Iſm.
sp.p: You're obliging Gentlemen, there's half womankind condemn'd already.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: Then there's your devout ſouls, that ſigh and whine, have ſomething of Religion in their very gate; and never ſpeak but in a tone of zeal and purity.

sp.speaker: Piſ.
sp.p: Pox on them, I muſt be hungry indeed to feed there; they are too common, and uſually belong to a whole fraternity: If they can but learn to call their ſins by new names, they paſs for vertues; and ſhe that ſins deepeſt is the trueſt Saint.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: No, no, they're your brisk Ladies that are the hardeſt conqueſt. 'Tis true you give us ſo much freedom, we can't find confidence to ask more, yet when we caſt it all up it ſignifies—juſt nothing.

sp.speaker: Ped.
sp.p: Or if we do venture to ask, 'tis but loſt labour, you'l never underſtand us, but wheadle't off with a laugh or ſome odd ſtory.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: Well Gentlemen we're beholden to you that our Honor's ſafe in your opinions.

sp.speaker: Ped.
sp.p: And that acknowledgment is all the recompence we're like to have.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: For all I can perceive Sir.

sp.speaker: Piſ.
sp.p: But conſider a little: is there no little inclinations, no beatings here—Madam more than ordinary?

sp.speaker: Iſm.
sp.p: No Sir I can find no ſuch matter.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: But ſuppoſe that to your freedom I ſhould offer that, which uſes to be ſweeter to your Sex, Revenge too?

sp.speaker: Iſm.
sp.p: Revenge would do ſomething could I get ſhut of you once, but I ſwear you're grown ſo troubleſome.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: In ſhort then, Madam, you reſolve to loſe both, deſert the publick cauſe, and—

sp.speaker: Iſm.
sp.p: I have no natural in-bred hatred to your perſon; and Revenge does tempt a little. But—
Let me die, if I can make objections, I ſhall hold out no longer.

div.stage: Enter Antonio's Boy in womans cloaths.

sp.speaker: Piſ.
sp.p: Whom do you ſeek Lady?

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.p: Antonio Sir.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: Your Servant Madam, hang me if I knew you at the firſt glance. Thou com'ſt luckily: be ſure not to be amaz'd at whatſoe're I ſay or do, but anſwer me in my own ſtrain.

sp.speaker: Iſm.
sp.p: Who is this? they're mighty well acquainted Sir methinks.

sp.speaker: Piſ.
sp.p: Faith Madam I can't gueſs, ſhe's very fair.

sp.speaker: Iſm.
sp.p: But well: I know ſome Ladies will not be aſhamed to ſhevv their faces in her company. Would I could blaſt that little beauty that ſhe has.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: I thought our loves vvould ne're admit of jealouſie, but thou art too kind.

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.p: 'Tis you have made me ſo, I were ingrateful Sir indeed ſhould I not endeavour to return your love.

sp.speaker: Iſm.
sp.p: Hovv's this? Return his love? then I am vvretched.

sp.speaker: Piſ.
sp.p: You ſeem angry Madam.

sp.speaker: Iſm.
sp.p: Not I Sir, 'tis not in the povver of man to make me ſo, Aſide but that vvoman does.

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.p: You think me Sir too free I fear.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: No deareſt, our old love may challenge this and more.

sp.speaker: Iſm.
sp.p: May they poiſon thee.

sp.speaker: Ped.
sp.p: I ſmell it, 'tis Antonio's Boy he courts. And ſhe muſt love by her concern. Now I'le ſtrike home.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: You have your ſtory ready for Camillo.

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.p: Yes Sir.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: And you'l not fail to meet me there Deareſt?

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.p: I ſhall ne're deny my ſelf a happineſs.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: But are you ſure my Siſter will be found ſo eaſy as to yield?

sp.speaker: Ped
sp.p: I only beg the promiſe that you'l follow her example.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p:
I may have confidence enough in her to grant,
and yet ſhew little kindneſs. Aſide at worſt it ſaves my bluſhes.

sp.speaker: Ped.
sp.p: That little's all I ask, Madam.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: I'le only end a formal compliment or two.

sp.speaker: Iſm.
sp.p: Treacherous baſe man!

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: Piſauro, ſhall I beg you would conduct this Lady?

sp.speaker: Piſ.
sp.p: You honor me with the truſt.

sp.speaker: Iſm.
sp.p: Will you go Siſter?

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: You'l give me leave to wait on you Madam.

sp.speaker: Iſm.
sp.p: No Sir, you have your hands full I ſee already, and may ſpare your formal compliments. Would you fail your aſſignation with ſo great a beauty?

sp.speaker: Am.
sp.p: As I could wiſh. She is not ugly Madam.

sp.speaker: Iſm.
sp.p: I don't intend a quarrel on the ſubject. 'Tis indifferent to me what ſhe is.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: I ſee it is Madam; nor could you blame me for courting her, when I found you ſo cruel.

sp.speaker: Iſm.
sp.p: I blame you? Why did you not leave Piſauro here, and go your ſelf? there's no body ſo fond of your company. Come Siſter. to Pedro I hope Sir you'l be ſo kind as to ſhew us the way home.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: Nay fie Siſter part friends. to Pedro You ſee Sir we are like to meet.

sp.speaker: Ped.
sp.p: I'le take my fortune Madam, Aſide and know I have a ſure card to play.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: 'Tis pretty to fall from the diſcourſe of marriage into this of chiding.

sp.speaker: Iſm.
sp.p: Marriage? I'le rather be ſhut up with Leandro in a grave, than ever have a thought of you.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: But I'me ſure you will; more, know you muſt. Nay what is more yet, am confident 'twill be a match.

sp.speaker: Iſm.
sp.p: Now you're impudent. Did I ever ſhew the leaſt kindneſs to you?

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: Confeſt, but this anger makes me think you have had no unkindneſs for me.

sp.speaker: Iſm.
sp.p: To vex you, I will confeſs it true, but add to it, that I hate you now.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: 'Tis very ſtrange, all that you can ſay, can never make me believ't.

sp.speaker: Iſm.
sp.p: I tell you I ſhould hate my ſelf, ſhould I ever have the leaſt good thought of you. Nay I ſhall hate all mankind for your ſake, ſcarce ſpare my Brother for beginning our acquaintance.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: This ſtill confirms me more in my opinion.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: This is mad courtſhip.

sp.speaker: Ped.
sp.p: I know it muſt ſucceed, for nothing heightens love ſo much as a miſgrounded jealouſie.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: What if I would promiſe, I would love no woman beſides you? is there no hopes of pardon?

sp.speaker: Iſm.
sp.p: No, I ſcorn it now.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: If I ſwear I never did love a woman?

sp.speaker: Iſm.
sp.p: Nothing. I know it falſe, and if I doated on you, ſhould hate you for this lie.

sp.speaker: Tut.
sp.p: Ladies, you muſt thiſt for yourſelves, and that with ſpeed: your Father is awake, has ſent for Leandro; and to the Senate, that he may force you home, where e're he finds you.

sp.speaker: Ped.
sp.p: You know your old retreat.

sp.speaker: Iſm.
sp.p: I'le die firſt.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: And I'le be as good as my word, and follow my Siſter.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: Now I begin to find I'me wretched.
If this unlucky woman had not come I had been happy.

sp.speaker: Iſm.
sp.p: And I more miſerable far than now. Come Siſter let's fly any whither from theſe men.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: Pray ſtay Madam, ſince I have work't you to a height, and am confirm'd you love me by this jealouſie, know that Lady was my Boy, dreſt in that habit to procure your liberty. I knew I had no other way to make this bleſt diſcovery. Will you yet give me leave?

sp.speaker: Iſm.
sp.p: I am worſe angry than before to be betrai'd by this trick.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: Conſider Madam you'd better do't, I'le make good my promiſe, liberty and Revenge.

sp.speaker: Iſm.
sp.p: No, no ſuch matter: it may be I'le vouchſafe to hear your ſtory out.

sp.speaker: Tut.
sp.p: A minutes ſtay will ruine all.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: What do you reſolve on Siſter?

sp.speaker: Iſm.
sp.p: Only that I will not have Leandro.

sp.speaker: Ped.
sp.p: My hopes are fair yet Madam.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: You know the grounds on which they ſtand.

sp.speaker: Tut.
sp.p: Away I ſay. I eaſily gueſs where this quarrel will end.

sp.speaker: Cam.
sp.p: Never plead for them, to be made the talk and ſtory of all the town, Sung in Ballads, for't will come to that; The careful father gull'd, or old Camillo's dream, I can, nor will hear no more.

sp.speaker: Lean.
sp.p: Threatning will but make them fly your fury: whereas a promiſe of pardon brings them with ſubmiſſion into your power, and then you may contrive their puniſhment.

sp.speaker: Cam.
sp.p: Contrive? do you hear me?

For the firſt I'le have a dungeon ſo dark and ſtreight that ſhe ſhall grope the way unto her mouth, and have no other air but ſighs to live on. The ſecond you ſhould never wed, did I not believe you would invent ſome laſting terrors unto all that are or ſhall be Wives.

sp.speaker: Lea.
sp.p: Truſt me with that: but firſt it's neceſſary, I ſeek'em out, and bring them home.

sp.speaker: Cam.
sp.p: If they refuſe, uſe force; the Senate cannot deny their power to ſo juſt deſigns.

sp.speaker: Lea.
sp.p: I hope we ſhall not need it.

sp.speaker: Cam.
sp.p: Never was man at my age ſo rid.
To be rock't aſleep like a great Baby, whilſt they are all a revelling. Well, I ſhall meet with theſe dap-chicks: That Jay my ſon, with the Owl his Tutor, and if I do—
Hah! who have we here?

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.p: You may wonder at a ſtrangers rudeneſs Sir, and why a woman thus intrudes.

sp.speaker: Cam.
sp.p: By my troth ſo I do, but the Divel's in you all for impudence.

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.p:
When you know I have neceſſity and Juſtice on
my ſide, I cannot doubt but you'l relieve my miſery.

sp.speaker: Cam.
sp.p: A beggar in this garb! be gon, I have no time to hear long ſtories, nor will to ſupply your wants.

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.p: To relieve my wants will never make you poorer Sir.

sp.speaker: Cam.
sp.p: The right religious Cant to? you know the way, be gon.

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.p: Pray hear me out, and then I know you will have pitty.
If e're you had a Mother, you owed a duty to, or wife you lov'd.

sp.speaker: Cam.
sp.p: 'Tis a pretty tone this.

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.p: If you have daughters, as I knovv you have, whoſe honor you'd preſerve from ſtain: if any thing that's yet more dear, by all I do conjure you to hear me out.

sp.speaker: Cam.
sp.p: Now am I ſuch a Coxcomb, that though I know it is a cheat, yet I muſt liſten, come riſe and begin then.

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.p: This moſt unhappy woman that you ſee, whoſe little beauty tears and grief have turn'd to ruins, yet was once thought fair, till perjury and all that's falſe weeps O falſe Leandro!

sp.speaker: Cam.
sp.p: How! was't not Leandro that ſhe nam'd? What can this mean?

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.p: Till he falſe man by force and treachery, had raviſht all my wealth, and left me thus neglected.

sp.speaker: Cam.
sp.p: Come pray be plain, I'le hear you now with patience.

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.p: As ſoon as grief will let me Sir.

sp.speaker: Cam.
sp.p: There's no truſt in woman kind if this be falſe.

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.p: My Father was a Merchant, and accounted rich, his place of living Candy, whilſt alive, Heaven reſt his ſoul.

sp.speaker: Cam.
sp.p: This muſt be true, it moves me too. His name?

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.p: Fabricio. When the enemy approacht our walls, he was commander for this State, and in their Services loſt his life. 'Twas that unhappy minute, when I ſaw Leandro firſt, whoſe ſeeming goodneſs might have tempted one more wife, than miſerable me.

sp.speaker: Cam.
sp.p: Pray on. I long to hear thee out.

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.p:
In ſhort, my Mother truſted him with all concerns,
her wealth, her ſelf, and me. He liv'd a while a faithful Guardian. And I (for it muſt out) too ſoon lov'd.

sp.speaker: Cam.
sp.p: Your name Lady?

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.p: Fabia, in a word.

He promis'd to convey our family, and riches to this town, did ſo, but in the voyage, after a thouſand vows of Marriage, which we could not then conſummate, ſtole my honor, and ever ſince hath left me to my grief.

sp.speaker: Cam.
sp.p: Bleſt diſcovery, truſt me now I pitty thee.

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.p: If you pitty, help me Sir and ſave your ſelf, this ſame Leandro ſtill muſt needs be falſe, and will you throw away a Virgin on a perjur'd man? And if ſhe marries him, I'me loſt for ever.

sp.speaker: Cam.
sp.p: If I find this ſtory true, I'le promiſe that your Father's name's Fabritio, your's Fabia.
Hold, I think I hear him coming.
sp.stage: Enter Leandro, Antonio, Pedro, Mariana, Iſmena.
sp.p: Away, away, I have nothing to ſay to you. Nor you neither, you may return.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: We have buſineſs Sir that much concerns you.

sp.speaker: Cam.
sp.p: Let it be what it will I have no leiſure: if you will ſtay, come not near my daughters, but go you to that corner of the room, you to this; ſo the Divel's in you if you play tricks at this diſtance. My buſineſs is with Leandro.

sp.speaker: Lea.
sp.p: Your Pleaſure Sir.

sp.speaker: Cam.
sp.p: Only a little ſcruple, I remember I have ſworn, never to match my daughter with a man that had not hazarded his life to ſerve the State.

sp.speaker: Lea.
sp.p: That can be no Obſtacle. I've ſerv'd it long, and when our Candy was beſieged, ſent numbers of the infidels to ſeek their Prophet in the other world. This my friends can witneſs.

sp.speaker: Cam.
sp.p: You knew Fabritio then?

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: How it works?

sp.speaker: Lea.
sp.p:
Fabritio was my leader Sir, and train'd me up to Arms, many a bold ſally has he made, and brought back Victory,
nor did he tamely loſe his life, but fell encompaſs'd with an hoſt of ſlaughter'd enemies.

sp.speaker: Cam.
sp.p: Thus far we do agree. How fared it with his wife and daughter Sir? I have heard he left both.

sp.speaker: Lea.
sp.p: He did, and both patterns to the Sex. They ſhar'd the common fortune, and when the town was yielded up ſet ſail for Venice.

sp.speaker: Cam.
sp.p: Right yet.
How was the daughter call'd?

sp.speaker: Lea.
sp.p: Fabia. (What can all this mean?

sp.speaker: Cam.
sp.p: I am confirm'd.
Do you know this Lady?

sp.speaker: Lea.
sp.p: No Sir, nor till this minute ever ſaw her face.

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.p: O Perjur'd man! is Fabia ſo ſoon forgot? falſe, falſe Leandro.

sp.speaker: Cam.
sp.p: Pray look again.

sp.speaker: Lea.
sp.p: May I ne're enjoy the thing I love on earth, or when I die heaven—

sp.speaker: Cam.
sp.p: His ſtrong denials make me confident. Conſider once again, is not this Fabia?

sp.speaker: Fabia
sp.p: whom you have wrong'd?

sp.speaker: Lea.
sp.p: Neither Sir if you require oaths.

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.p: If oaths could have obliged, I never had become thus wretched.

sp.speaker: Lea.
sp.p: Heavens, that e're ſuch impudence ſhould wear the ſhape of women! wer't thou not ſo—

sp.speaker: Cam.
sp.p: Come, no threats Sir.
She's in a ſanctuary in my houſe. Take her, and make amends for all your former injuries.

sp.speaker: Lea.
sp.p: What injuries? you will diſtract me Sir, give me but a minute for to clear my ſelf.

sp.speaker: Cam.
sp.p: No, I am ſatisfied already, and will not be cheated, nor let my daughter run her ſelf to certain ruine. I'le in, and fetch the writing you have given.

sp.speaker: Lea.
sp.p: Hell and Furies.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: Save you Sir, how do you like your Iſland?

sp.speaker: Lea.
sp.p: Will you never leave your tortures?

sp.speaker: Ped.
sp.p: This is the hell we told you of, if you ventured to ſin again.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: As for your new diſcovery I have taken poſſeſſion, and it's like to be call'd by my name; in ſhort I am married to Iſmena, Pedro to Mariana, and this Fabia is the Boy dreſt up to amuſe Camillo.

sp.speaker: Ped.
sp.p: Here take him, you're ſo much an Italian, you need not loſe your Miſtreſs.

sp.speaker: Lea.
sp.p: You ſhall find me more by my Revenge.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: Thus far our plot ſucceeds.

sp.speaker: Boy,
sp.p: do you ſteal away and get undreſt: I would not have Camillo find that cheat yet.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: He's coming: To our places.

sp.speaker: Cam.
sp.p: Here, here, where's Leandro?

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: Gone Sir.

sp.speaker: Cam.
sp.p: And Fabia?

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: Yes Sir but not together.

sp.speaker: Cam.
sp.p: Then theſe muſt be ſent.

Now I have leiſure to come to you, Runagates, for though you have eſcaped this danger, you muſt not think to go free. I have provided for ye both, 'tis not your powder that can find another remedy, I will not eat nor drink till it's perform'd. I gueſs your buſineſs Gentlemen, but you may ſpare your pains.

sp.speaker: Cam.
sp.p: What can this prove?
We kneel for bleſſing Sir.

sp.speaker: Cam.
sp.p: I give it you; but who's this?

sp.speaker: Pac.
sp.p: Your Daughter, whilſt I call her wife.

sp.speaker: Cam.
sp.p: Still more wretched? Go fool thou haſt undone thy ſelf, and ſhalt live nor pittied nor relieved by me.
That I ſhould ever be a Father!
But I'le ſtudy to forget the name.
Theſe a Nunnery if poſſible ſhall ſave from ruine. In I ſay.

sp.speaker: Ant. Ped.
sp.p: That we forbid Sir.

sp.speaker: Cam.
sp.p: What ſhall I not rule my own family in my own houſe? In I ſay.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: They may with juſtice diſobey, they leave their husbands here.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: Who thus in duty ask your bleſſing.

sp.speaker: Cam.
sp.p: Bleſſing? e'ne the down-right Divel take you all, I am gull'd, cheated, fool'd.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: Oh Pedro, vve can never proſper if a fathers bleſſing be denied.

sp.speaker: Ped.
sp.p: Never fear Madam, a little patience reconciles all.

sp.speaker: Lyſ.
sp.p: Joy Gallants. Three vveddings in a day? the State can never vvant Souldiers.

sp.speaker: Pac.
sp.p: There's little joy belongs to me. The Reformation goes on too faſt novv; for though I like this marrying for love, I hate this damn'd Engliſh vvay of diſinheriting.

sp.speaker: Lyſ.
sp.p: What can this mean?

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: Nay faith the old Gentleman's ſtrangely angry, prithee try vvhat you can do Lyſander, your acquaintance has been great.

sp.speaker: Lyſ.
sp.p: I vvill, I'me confident vvhen once he knovvs your qualities, he'l think his daughters vvell beſtovv'd, and an only Sons pardon is ſoon obtain'd.

sp.speaker: Iſm.
sp.p: However it ſucceed, I'de rather run a thouſand dangers than be ſlave to Leandro's jealouſie. This vvas a brave revenge done like a Maſter of your Art.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: That part of my promiſe is fulfill'd then; but novv 't's too late to bargain for your liberty, you're at my mercy ſtill.

sp.speaker: Iſm.
sp.p: I thought it beſt to truſt you.
I knevv a promiſe vvas ſooner broke, than your good nature turn'd.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: Hovvever of my ovvn accord I here ingage to be true, until I find you falſe, and then I • le take Lyſander's pattern.

sp.speaker: Iſm.
sp.p:
Then here I promiſe for you, that you alvvays ſhall
be true. I ever lov'd the talk of liberty, more than the thing it ſelf.

sp.speaker: Ped.
sp.p: You Mariana, may challenge all the freedom that you'l take.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: I ſhall take the leſs, for your giving me ſo much.

sp.speaker: Nurſe.
sp.p: I have found my tongue again, and if I don't rail you all deaf—

sp.speaker: Ped.
sp.p: Say you ſo, I have the other gag for you.

sp.speaker: Piſ.
sp.p: Pray Gentlemen, reckon it a conſiderable piece of Reformation, that we have found out two infallible remedies, to cure an old womans talking.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: How is't? where is he?

sp.speaker: Lyſ.
sp.p: He's come unto himſelf again, now he conſiders who you are, and follows me.
Well met Madam, I hope you're pleas'd.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.p: Since you are ſo cruel as to part, I muſt allow you truly noble.

sp.speaker: Lyſ.
sp.p: I doubt Piſauro ſome of theſe fine feathers muſt molt.

sp.speaker: Piſ.
sp.p: You're deceived Sir, with theſe I intend to purchaſe a rich wife, and pay ſome of my old ſcores to Juliana.

sp.speaker: Cam.
sp.p: Heaven bleſs you; and if you can live on that, do. But I am ſo much a Reformer, as not to part with a farthing of money, without ſettlement, Gentlemen.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: That ſhall never breed a difference.

sp.speaker: Cam.
sp.p: I knew your Father well Antonio; if you prove as well, my daughter's happy.
Your's Pedro, for ſo I 'me told you're cal'd, is my peculiar friend, and if he likes the match, I will do any thing that's juſt.
But what can you pretend to, with your Gimcracks and travels, hah?

sp.speaker: Pac.
sp.p:
I married Sir for love and Virtue, and have heard you ſay it was your fault (if it may be accounted one)
when you took my Mother; I only follow'd your example.

sp.speaker: Tut.
sp.p: Well nick't Pupil.

sp.speaker: Cam.
sp.p: H'as found my weak ſide, it muſt not be denied. Well, you ſhall be upon your good behavior.

sp.speaker: Pac.
sp.p: If it comes to that I know I ſhall ſoon win him.

sp.speaker: Tut.
sp.p: I'le give you Lectures for't to morrow.
My gold's good Sir.

sp.speaker: Piſ.
sp.p: Yes this little Pinnace ſailes to fetch it home.

sp.speaker: Lel.
sp.p: And will bring it too, I'le warrant you.

sp.speaker: Cam.
sp.p: Come you ſhall all dine with me, we will be ſo long friends at leaſt.
If two of theſe adventures come off well, I have made a ſaving voyage.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: I have ſomething to do ſtill, which is the Reforming of you Mounſieur Tutor. Nay never ſhrink, for one of theſe things muſt be ſubſcribed to, either chuſe to renounce your intereſt in the Society.

sp.speaker: Tut.
sp.p: That's hard.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: Or your pretence to Poetry, and acquaintance with the Muſes as you call't.

sp.speaker: Tut.
sp.p: Harder yet.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: Or engage in three months, to produce a Play which ſhall have nothing in't borrow'd, nor improbable, nor prophane, nor bawdy.

sp.speaker: Tut.
sp.p: This is almoſt impoſſible, but yet I'le venture, and if my Play miſcarries here, ſet ſail for England, where any one of theſe qualities will make it famous.

sp.speaker: Ped.
sp.p: Now it's perfect, Antonio.
sp.l: We're married, yet can know no jealouſie.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: And Siſter we are wives, and yet are free.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: Bleſt Reformation!
sp.l: All's right, we ſhould have nothing left to do,
Could we Reform one Engliſh cuſtom too,
That's the damn'd trade of cenſuring in you.

div.head: EPILOGUE.
div.l: HOw do you like our Reformation now?
Come, we're amongſt our ſelves. Here are Wits too.pointing to Pacheco and Tutour.
Or ſhall's to th' Coffee-houſe and there debate,
Each take his Chair and Pipe and judg in State?
Lord how they wait a Wit that's fam'd in Town!
He lookes about him with a ſcornful frown,
Then picks his Favourite out and ſits him down.
Take me how is't? Have you ſeen our new Play?
Yes faith; and how? a half Crown thrown away,
Pox on't he cries, I Droll'd and Slept it out;
'Twas ſome Raw Fop: Then proudly ſtares about;
Then ſhrugs and whiſpers, laughs, then ſwears aloud.
The whilst there's ſilence kept by all the Croud.
At length he nods and cocks, is heard to ſay,
D— me 'tis true, and thus he damns the Play,
Riſes, lookes big and combs, then goes his VVay.
'Tis ſtrange to think how abſolute they are,
VVhen lookes, half VVords and Oathes, deſtroy or ſpare.
VVe can expect no favour; theſe are known
Foes unto every thing that's not their own.
And rather too, than that ſhall want applauſe,
They'l clap themſelves and that way gain the cauſe.
By ſuch like Arts they rule the ſtage and you,
And what was Favour firſt, now claim as due.
For ſhame uſe your Authority and free
Your ſelves from theſe uſurpers Tyranny,
Ne're wait their cenſure more, but let them know
You have the power that they pretended to.
They wheadle you to clap bad plays they write:
To be reveng'd do you clap this to night.
But Ladies you our Author hopes to find
In your own Cauſe and for your own ſakes kind,
Since 'tis the firſt deſign of's Poetry
Both how to gain and give you Liberty.
